content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Definitely one of the best games in my life. Though I finished the game but I still play it. Final Fantasy XIII is a JRPG type game where character development matters more. You need to fight against many enemies to gain a so called Crystarium points. There are 6 characters in the game and you can choose which 3 characters would you take to battle. Beating enemies will give all characters the same Crystarium points. The story is very linear until you reach chapter 11. At chapter 11 you will get to Gran Pulse that is sorrunded with many Cie'th Stones that grant you side mission. There are a total of 60 side missions. Their difficulty is from E-A. Once you defeat Orphan (the final and not the hardest boss) you will grant access to Crystarium level 5 where you can max out all your characters and face Vercigentorix (the toughest boss in the game). The battle system is a paradigm system. There are a total of 6 paradigms: Commando, Ravager, Sentinel, Synergist, Saboteur and Medic roles. You can create 6 different paradigms. During the battle you need to switch between paradigms by using the TAB button on your keyboard. Once you are used to it it can be quite a fun. Mouse is supported in the game for camera control. Game audio is available in English and Japanese. Among the Final Fantasy XIII series I would rate this game as 10/9.

content:
Posted: March 11
												I've beaten the game on ps3 and 360, only played about 14 hours so far on steam. Final Hallway XIII gets a bad rap. Yes, it is a linear RPG that made the unfortunate choice of putting the first section of the game literally "on rails" (a railroad), and it is absolutely true that it takes upwards of 20-30 hours before you get to the open world sections. People tend to forget that the most beloved "open world" final fantasies only felt open world: you could go to your choice of 2 or 3 new areas or backtrack, not travel wherever you wanted. This mis-remembrance is really the source of most of the game's hate, in several areas.First, the aforementioned linearity. Second, unlikable characters (apart from 9, and now 15, I believe this is true of ALL final fantasy titles).Third, "oversimplified combat." This is the one that irks me the most. People complain that the paradigm system encourages you to "just mash x" with no strategy. These people must have not progressed very far in the game, because managing sentinel and healer roles while preventing your stagger bar from depleting with damage classes is a difficult balance to strike. As for "mashing x," this is what you do in every. turn. based. rpg. ever. You cycle up the attack command or whatever skill you're spamming, and mash x as fast as you can. the only difference here is that you can use libra or fight the same enemy type repeatedly to have your characters learn what spell is the best. How does this change the traditional RPG experience?Instead of scrolling through lightning and blizzard to get to fire, the character learns that fire is most effective and auto ques it for you, which you push X to confirm.Don't believe the hate. It's an engaging and beautiful (graphical fidelity still holds up today) game that gets you 50+ hours of gameplay for around 20 bucks.

number of helpful: 32 of 48 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Let's get this out of the way - There are 2 camps of people that either love the game or hate it and they seem to be quite even in population. You might end up on either one of them and I am personaly on the "I like this" no scratch that "I FREAKING LOVE THIS GAME" side. Now than;If you are here for a classic ARPG experience (as in: open world, many towns, bunch of NPCs with all sorts of cool or less cool side quests) you are not going to find that here BUT WAIT, DON'T LEAVE YET. The fact that this game is different doesn't mean it's bad.You are not going to find yourself running around through he whole world of Final Fantasy XIII like in previous games, in fact it's ~80% linear experience, you will have to wait a while before the game opens up for you. Where the game opens up is in Chapter 11, you will get to explore pretty big area(s) with challanging content, you will get to form your own team and strategize alot during tough battles in side quests (if you choose to do them and honestly, you should do at least some of them or you are not going to be able to progress in chapter 12 IMO).But getting to Chapter 11 will take you 20-30 hours (depending on your play style) and the first 10 chapters is just "hold A to win" type of gameplay. But the story will keep pushing you forward! And my oh my, if you like well written stories you might like this one. It's a bit confusing at the begining, you have no idea who you are and who the people you meet are. You don't know what you are doing here and what's happening, but keep on going and you will uncover everything. Don't forget to read logs often because in these you'll find even more information that will help clear things up for you. And really check the logs often, because logs about people you meet often change, you don't want to miss out.And just when you think you know everything, the game still has secrets for you prepared. All in all the story is really strong part of this game, if you find that you don't like it, just keep on going, maybe you'll like it more once you know more.The characters have strong personalities and they go through alot, I got really invisted in most of them and while some may seem bad, I feel that they are like that for a reason.Since I mentioned the combat already. It's rather simplistic at the begining, you just choose auto-battle, your character is aoutomaticly going to choose what's best to do and it's going to do just that. You are controlling just 1 character all the time while the party have maximum of 3 characters in it. You can't switch to other character to do anything with them, you are pretty much forced to play as the leader all the time. But don't worry, the AI is great, they are not messing up at all. You can choose not to "aouto-battle" and attack however you want by lining up abilities to the queue. If that's what you want to do, just switch the battle in options to slow as you want to have some time to choose how you want to attack. All the characters can have 3 out of 6 different roles (later on all of them, but they are generaly good only in the main 3) and you can switch roles during battle at any time but only to previously created presets (there are 7 presets available that you can modify however you want). So if your starting stance is - Commander, ravanger, ravanger you can switch to Commander, Sentinel, Medic at any time if you have this kind of preset created. And your companions will behave differently in battle. This strategic gameplay makes it not so simplistic anymore and is quite fun to play with. Once you get to chapter 11 it's all just great!You will find all sorts of accessories and weapons through the game, they might not look powerful and you are not going to find much better stuff. While your characters are not leveling like in classic RPG game, you can level up your weapons and accessories with items you find after battles. Make your research with weapons. Each character can get many different weapons but they all have similiar starting statistics. But if you level them up to maximum level, they differ alot! You don't want to end up leveling a weapon the whole game only to find out it's the weakest of them all too late.While your characters aren't leveling up, they gain Crystarium Points (or CP) after each battle and with that you can improove them in their roles. It's nothing complex, there's no massive tree where you could mess up your character, it's all straight forward. And you will unlock all abilities here too. All the magic comes from Crystarium, so you are not going to be buying magic or anything like that.The game looks amazing! Just great, it's the best looking Final Fantasy game released ATM. I still remember when I've been playing FF VIII many years ago thinking how cool it would be if the game looked like the cutscenes... Well this is even better and I felt like it's a dream coming true. There are many cutscenes that just blew me away with the ammount of creativity in them, the game just looks wonderful.The game even sounds great! What do you expect? It's final fantasy after all. If there's somethign that never change it's the music. I found myself denying faster travel through the locations of Chapter 11 just so I can listen to the wonderfull music there.Did I tell you how great the story is? I am not spoiling anything here, you should just enjoy it for yourself! I personaly found the story of Final Fantasy XII weak, but on the other hand I prefered the gameplay there more. Here it's wonderful story with weaker gameplay (but with rich elements as I wrote above). I was touched, I was scared, I was happy and sad. The emotions are there and they are not going to go away untill you are back in the main menu after the ending credits.Now for the main reason you might hate this game. The freaking port. Yeah... it's not great, it's lazy as hell. For reference. I have GTX 780 (MSI OC Gaming edition) and Intel Core i5-4440 3.1GHz. Running at 1080p with maxed out graphical settings (there's not alot of them mind you, shadow resolution, filtering, resolution... And that's about it I believe) the game ran great for the most part (60fps) but I've been dealing with heavy stuttering. That is happening if you don't have USB controller pluged in to your PC. The game is aparently looking for the controller which is causing the stutter. You can fix that by disabling all ""HID-Compliant Devices" in "Device Manager". More info here -> http://www.reddit.com/r/FinalFantasy/comments/2it9rz/stuttering_in_ff_xiii_pc_try_this_worked_for_me/THAT you should not have to do no matter what, one big BOO for you Square Enix.But that's not all, in certain areas the game would drop to 30 fps for no bloody reason. Narrow Corridor? suddenly 30 fps. It doesn't make the game not playable but it's frustrating. For me, there were only 2 areas in the game where it dropped below 30fps but only for a few seconds, nothing to really complain about but it makes you wonder "why the hell?".Other than that the game ran great on my machine. And I don't think it's getting any better even if you have 10 times better PC than me, aparently the game utilizes only 1 GPU core or whatever (I am not good at this stuff, that's only what I heard on the internet) so it can only get worst if you do not meet recommended requirements. Also aparently on AMD cards it's quite bad, can't comment on that personaly tho.I still heavily recommend this game! It's bloody cheap for what it has to offer. I mean come on 13€? Yeah I can forgive you the bad port for this price, I would still love to see it running better tho. So even if you are not sure if you'd like this game, it's not going to cost you much to just try it out. It offers many hours of gameplay and I enjoyed every single minnute of this game. Now I don't know what to do, complete all achievement or play XIII-2? Hmm... Anyway. JUST BLOODY BUY IT ALREADY.

												 Mom dies in front of her kid, friend of kid says, "aw, it's too much, isn't it" then giggles and runs off.That's the writing in a nutshell.  That being said, graphics are always good, which is the main selling point of FF series, however, combat is extremely dumbed down to the point where you only control one character per combat. I used to love past FF games, but this is just watching a movie while you're constantly trying to skip the combat to get to the next scene.  That's how boring combat is.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												After putting more then 60 hours into the game, I finally completed the main story. There is still plenty left to do after the main story is completed, but I don't think I have the energy to put more hours into it just yet. I did complete this game many years ago on Ps3 but been feeling an itch to play a Final Fantasy game since FFXV is being delayed, so decided to purchase this on Steam and complete it.For those who haven't played it yet, but have played other Final Fantasy games - the rumours are true, the game is very linear. The infamous YouTube video of "Final Hallway XIII - JonTron" or maybe, better known as: "THE GAMES PLAYING ITSELF, JON!" is rather true. A lot of the game is running in one direction and pressing 'Auto-battle' in a fight. But if you can get past this, the game has a lot to offer. A deep story, that sometimes is a little confusing but still great. Character development to the point you can feel a connection and perhaps even an emotion towards them during some scenes. And large content, this game is filled with side quests (from Chapter 11) and achievements, and plenty more to do after the game is completed. I would highly reccomend this game, it definitely keeps you occupied.Overall, it isn't the best Final Fantasy game ever made, so don't jump into expecting it to be that good, but also don't believe some of the people on here saying it's the worst Final Fantasy, because that's just a blatant lie. If you can get around the horrible port by using some guides online, you can expect pretty solid 30fps throughout the game, with 60fps here and there, which is nice.I give it a strong 8/10, definitely worth a play if you haven't yet!

number of helpful: 50 of 82 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 15
												I hated this game...not everything, but most of it.  Let me first start with the positives.Pros:Battle System - The battlesystem is more action-oriented than previous incarnations of Final Fantasy series.  While I prefer the old-fashion ATB style Final Fantasies, I think the Paradigm battle system does make the fight sequences less of a drag and keeps my blood pressure slightly elevated.  The Paradigm system simplifies and streamlines the commands of the party and keeps the fights engaging.Graphics - As of this writing, Final Fantasy 13 is nearly 7 years old since worldwide release.  The performance enhancement provided by the PC port gives the game an extended lifetime as far as visuals go.  Oddly enough, the FMV suffers the most and looks grainy compared to the smoother in-game graphics with the port.  There's no denying Final Fantasy 13 is a gorgeous game.PC Port - I was concerned that the porting of this game from the console would result in many bugs and glitches that would hamper my enjoyment of the game.  Surprisingly, there were few bugs that I found distracting.  This is a terrific port as far as PC ports goes.  As such, bugs and glitches did not hamper my enjoyment of the game...the enjoyment hampering was the result of a multitude of other issues which I'll discuss next.Cons:Story - Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥..the story is convoluted!  Even until the very end, the story didn't straighten itself out much.  So the basic premise (from what I understand), is that the floating world of Cocoon (which is essentially a moon with a big hole on its side) and the larger planet, Gran Pulse are at odds with each other.  The deity-like entities, called Fal Cie, appear to be warring with each other...though it is never made clear why they're not buddies.  Although the Fal Cie do have tremendous powers, they are limited in the manners they able to wield said powers.  Just think of a dragcar attempting to go down a 25mph residential neighbohood.  In other words, they're powerful beings that are trapped in their respective worlds.  The Fal Cie can, however, directly influence humans.  Once such way is to give human's a "focus"...aka task.  Upon completing their focus, they are awarded immortality by being converted to a crystalline form.  If they fail their task, they are then turned into these miserable, mindless creatures called Cieth.  This is the Fal Cie's way of getting around their limitations.  The Fal Cie are limited in what they can influence, but humans have no such limitations.  Humans can do anything they want.  The Fal Cie realizes this and exploits human freedom of choice to enact their own agendas against the other's world.  In comes Lighting, Snow, Sazh, Hope, Fang, and Vanille.  The main plot revolves around the six of them as they try to figure out what their focuses are and how to complete it.  The game explores several themes, but the biggest recurring theme is free will vs. destiny as they try reconcile their own interests, the interest of the people of Cocoon, and the interests of the Fal Cies.  So that's the overall, broadstroke gist of the it all.  Like I said, I hate the story.  I found it hard to connect with the characters.  The voice acting didn't make it easy (I think Sazh was the best voice-acting in the bunch).  I thought the motivations of the antagonists were really esoteric and not very compelling.  I didn't feel the comraderies and bond between the characters...and that's not for a lack of trying on the writer's part.  The characters have their own set of baggages and there was plenty of story built-in to cement those relationships as they resolve their problems together....but it was never quite convincing or compelling to me.  Most of the time, I found the characters were just down-right annoying.  Worst of all, the story was confusing to me...and just when I thought I had some of it straightened out, a new plot twist was tossed in to make it more muddled!  After about the 10th hour of the game, I just didn't care anymore and rushed the rest of the game to finish it.  I've played every single Final Fantasy game (except part 15), and I have to say...this is one of the ♥♥♥♥♥iest story for me.  I liked part 9, as far as story and characters go, the most...just to give you a sense of where I'm coming from.Character progression - The character progression is kinda crappy.  To make your characters more powerful, Final Fantasy 13 gives you the Crystallarium system.  You collect CP when dispatching monsters and then, in turn, you use the CP to move along this grid to reach the next status, spell, or itemization upgrade.  The system is not very deep, and doesn't provide much in the way of variability of your characters.  It's simple, just collect a lot of CP and apply it to the Crystallarium grid.  There some choices that the player has to make when using CP on the grid...do you apply your points to the Commander grid or the Ravager or Medic grid?  There are some forks in the grid, but it's not a big deal because if you earn enough CP, you can get the skill or stats of either fork.  There's no real consequences for picking one path over another because nothing gets locked out.  They may as well have just stuck to the ol' tried and true 'gain xp points to level up', because this system has about the same amount of depth.  It's very linear and not fun to play with. Exploration - Or rather...lack thereof!  The game is reputed to be an RPG corridor...I now understand why.  There's no real exploration in the game.  There are no towns or dungeons...or even NPC to talk to!  The game is very linear and plays as if it were on rails.  The options are few and obstensibly, the outcomes are the same.  The closest the game comes to an open world is at chapter 11 where you finally make it to the world of Gran Pulse....or a small section of it I should say.  On Gran Pulse, you can pick up missions from these Cieth Stones (people who have turned to Cieth and then subsequently to stones.  These Cieth Stones asks that you complete their focuses for them.  The missions are fairly simple...find monster X...and then kill monster X.  There are various rewards for completing the missions including items, weapons, and weapon upgrade materials....but ultimately, by the point in the game, I didn't want to do any of them if it required backtracking.  As I mentioned earlier, I just wanted to be done with the game by hour 10.Overall Feel of the game - I might have been fine with the game if were called something else other than Final Fantasy.  For me, FF13 didn't feel like a Final Fantasy game.  The world, although beautiful, did not feel alive and interactive to me.  The signature icons of Final Fantasies made appearances, but none of them in the manner they appeared in other FF games.  The Chocobos were just a part of the Sazh's plotline as he resolved his issues with Vanille and his son.  The Moogles didn't really make an appearance, but instead is a part of a menu on the save selection options.  Some of the creatures were familiar...like the Behemoths and flan....but most of the creatures were reskins (how many sabretooth tiger skins can there be?!?!).  Although, I must admit the Adamantoise was pretty cool.  Lets see...oh yeah, the equipment management was really shaved down...but I think that's been the trend since FFX, I think.  There was no vehicle travel...going from A to B was all on foot.  The world isn't too big, so travel time isn't much of an issue...it just doesn't feel right.  Even FFX had an airship at the end where you can land at preselection destinations.  No such thing in FF13.  The game's feel was too much of a departure from what I knew and love of the Final Fantasy series.  As such, it's hard to recommend this game to fans of the series....but at the same time, if you're a true Final Fantasy fan like I am, you'll suffer through this game like I did.I will rate this game a 4/10.

Posted: January 8
												A very pretty game with good music, likeable characters, and an interesting storyline. Combat is also engagingly innovative for about 30 hours.Unfortunately it suffers from terrible writing, incredibly linear (nearly nonexistent) level design, and awful pacing issues. It is, essentially, a 50 hour walk down a relatively boring but nice looking and occasionally emotionally satisfying hallway - and the hallway gets significantly more boring and difficult around the 25-30 hour mark.I enjoyed parts of this game, but it was just too underwhelming for me to recommend. It suffers from being an oppressive slog for the latter half of the game. Unless you're a die hard Final Fantasy fan or really want to play a more modern (is it even?) JRPG and can get it for sale, I wouldn't recommend it.

												I won't pass judgement on the actual game yet, but the port is horrendous. No sound options, limited video options, runs like absolute garbage on a 6700k/GTX970, with very low CPU and GPU utilization. It's not even that it's crazy demanding and the hardware can't handle it, it's just a poorly optimized, bloated console port. I suppose it's better than nothing, but this sort of attitude will only lead to other ports like this. Square Enix needs to be praised for bringing the Final Fantasy games to PC, but they also need to be heaviliy criticized for half-assing it. I guess if you're ok with highly inconsistent framerates, the complete lack of audio sliders and a very, VERY limited options menu, give it a go. It's certainly better than what you're gonna get on the previous gen consoles (PS3;Xbox360), it does look really, really good for a relatively older title and it's also cheaper than a lot of the old FF games on Steam. This is probably the most cautious recommendation I'm ever gonna give to a game (not that anyone cares).

												----------------------------------------------------------------------Updated Review----------------------------------------------------------------------If like me this is your first time playing FFXIII, I would definately recommend this game.  It has an interesting combat system and awesome cut scenes, with lots of character development.  Well worth the price.  If however you have previously played this game on the consoles I would not recommend this game.  After all it is the exact same game you have already played.  There are no graphical improvements, no added quests, items, weapons, etc..  With only a slight increase in framerate & achievements thrown into the mix.--------------------------------------------------------------------------Original Review--------------------------------------------------------------------------.I definately recommend this game.  It may be linear, but the combat is fun and fairly complex.  The story is pretty good, Each of the characters in your party has their own history and motivation.  The cinematics and world are beautifully rendered.  This is my first time playing ffxiii but so far I am thoroughly enjoying the game.  As ports go, I jave played far worse.A lot of people have been saying negative things about the game, honestly I don't agree with some of those comments:1. The game is a massive 60Gb (When I first pre-ordered the game it was actually 30GB, but it only had English audio which upset a lot of fans, who then made a huge issue about it, even going so far as to start a petition to get SE to add Japanese audio to the game, which they then did, doubling the size of the game, so is it really SE's fault for the massive size when all thet were doing was listening to the fans?)2. Game locked at 720p (There's already an unofficial patch that unlocks 1080p)3. The only difference between the pc version and the ps3 version was increased framerate (What did you expect the game is only $16)4. They say don't buy the game so that SE has to make better next time (Seeing as one of the reasons the released FFxiii on pc was to see if it will be viable to release future ff games on pc, this means if only a few people buy ffxiii we will most likely see very few ff games coming to pc, this would mean no ffxv on pc)So far my game has run smoothly with no lag.  My pc specs: Windows 7 64 bitQuad core 2.6 Ghz4 GB RamGeforce GT 430So if you want a fun fantasy jrpg for only $16 and you want to increase the chance of more final fantasy games coming to pc buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I didn't want to write a review before 100%ing it to fully understand the shortcomings of this game. Now that I finally have, I can talk about it somewhat fairly. The truth is that there's so much wrong with this game that it's hard to recommend it to just anyone.I enjoyed the combat system. The faster paced paradigm shift system (similar FFX-2's ATB/dressphere system) was a refreshing take on the turn based combat that FF12's didn't really provide. Shift canceling/ATB canceling also provided a lot more depth into what may look like simple combat mechanics. The story was acceptable but had major pacing issues with the first 10 chapters feeling overextended, while the last 3 chapters were much more enjoyable and interesting, yet shorter. What really stands out in the game however, are the visuals. Everything from the prologue to the end is a gorgeous vista of sci-fi fantasy, with a decadent high-tech society clashing against a beautiful yet raw planetscape. Eden in particular stood out for me, with it's beautiful architecture and sci fi-esque atmosphere.However, the infamous graphical issues, the random crashes that occur and the ESC key essentially being a one button Alt+F4 are major issues in this game. It's depressing to see a fan-made fix that was made in one day is still the only option to fix this heavily broken game. Squenix recently patched, and I was hoping for some official fixes, but all we got was a simple pop-up change to ask if you really wanted to quit the game when you hit ESC. Not even an ingame message but for me it distorts the current game screen and freezes it. Only by Alt-Tabbing do I see an off screen dialog window box asking me whether I really want to exit the game. I knew Japanese pc ports had a terrible history, but this one is almost as bad as the Dark Souls port (at least we didn't need GFWL). Technical issues aside, the pacing is terrible, you don't actually get to use the full combat system for the first half of the game. Sidequests are replaced by what is essentially hunts from FF12, the Crystarium system of leveling is extremely shallow with the bare minimum of choice. Animations are often clunky and slow for the kind of fast paced combat the game uses. These are some of the most obvious probelms you'll encounter.Overall, it isn't a terrible game. However, it's got so much wrong with it'll be hard to finish or enjoy, even for the seasoned RPG fanatic. It's a definite oddity in the consistency we've seen in the FF series. While it did have some very good areas, it's crippled of it's potential. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone unless they had the tenacity to see it through, and even then they might regret it.

content:
Posted: February 19
												While i do understand the criticisms of regarding FF13 series and its deviation from the usual JRPG formula that FF series is known for, I do not understand the hate everyone seems to have for the actual story. During my xbox 360 days, i only bought used games and these titles (FF13) are probably one of the few non-multiplayer i bought at retail; and that was after playing it for 3 hours from gamefly. Loved the series storytelling from beginning to end. May not be for everyone, especially for hardcore FF fanboys, but definitely not a trash series.﻿Game Mechs: 6/10 - i do prefer the old formula - Open World vs. Linear (all 3 FF13 games) - time-based gameplay on a J-RPG (Lightning Returns) they should fire the retard that suggested this... seriously...Port Quality: 1/10 - first 2 games in this series were lazily ported, and the fact that they know its a poor port, yet did not even attempt to offer an official fix is a slight show of Square being full of themselves. They are lucky they can mooch off the name of their franchise to keep their business running, but I wonder sometimes until when can they keep doing this until everyone from their fanbase is completely fed up.Game OST: 8/10 - may not be for everyone, but loved it regardless. Have the Soundtrack of all 3 series in my iPhone.Visuals and Graphics: 9/10- decent gameplay visuals- and as to be expected from the newer generation of FFs the cinematics are beautiful- very anime based which is somewhat of a + in my booksGameplay: 5/10- Auto-battle needs to go. playing J-RPG is a homage to pen-and-paper RPG that need some degree of thinking and planning to sucessfully finish. This feature shi.ts on the concept and is a pathetic marketing tool designed to hand-hold casual players to reel them in longer. Square should recognize the fact that FF has always been successful all this time as a niche market and made them what they are today. There is no need to upset your current fan-base just to reel in a quick buck from people that will just buy your game and play for 1-5 hours. Casuals will always be casual. They can attempt to adjust or they can leave as simple as that.- Needs to be more populated. FF will always be a "grind-game" true RPGs in general are like that. Might be a good idea to populate your explorable areas more or scale the rewards as the player levels increase to alleviate the grind. The game does neither. Story: 10/10- One of the game's few saving graces. Despite bombing important aspects of the game. This is the main reason why I feel compelled to recommend the game despite its shortcomings. If you can get over the slightly annoying game mechs/linearity/and its garbage port quality. Watching the story unfold while you are playing is more than enough reward for the sacrifice you made. Can't remember any other game that made me cry so much for kicks. It's no Shakespeare, that's true and it does have plot holes littered around the series, but it gets the job done regardless. With each character having their own sense of purpose that moves you while your playing. I've never seen such a cliche premise (save the princess/save the world) told in such a complex mind-fu.ck kind of way.

												Let's see have seen alot of whining about this release, but nothing have to do with the actual gameplay. And that should be what matters, sure the game doesn't have 1080p atm so what? you don't think modders are working with this now? at least they didn't forget about 60FPS. Yes the game is locked at 720p is that bad? kinda but does that give this game a thumb down? no, do the game got graphic options? no not in-game but you can force things like AF and AA through Nvidia control panel or the equelant for AMD. So about the actual game? is it good? yes it's very good actually as good as the PS3 release. Why? because it's the same game. Are the controlls any good? yes they are actually very good i have tried this game with both gamepad and mouse and keyboard and you know what? the controlls are amazing. Final Fantasy XIII isn't just a game you merely enjoy. You fall in love with it. It's gorgeous worlds have you stopping to admire them in complete awe, while a graceful soundtrack massages your brain. Final Fantasy XIII is an amazing game. With an engrossing story and a thrilling new battle system, this is one title you can't afford to miss as an RPG fan. However, though it succeeds on the most important fronts, there are some notable areas where the game could have been better. The linear level design is a fairly large stumbling block, and if you are used to open-world games, it can make the entire experience feel a little claustrophobic.  i give the game 8/10 it's a very great game, it's not perfect but very close.

number of helpful: 166 of 300 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												The PC Port is atrocious as of now. Not only did they not bother making localization files optional downloads (Steam supports selective downloading of localization files), and have you thus install 60 gigabytes (49gb download) onto your machine, but they also failed to provide any sort of graphical options beyond Windowed/Fullscreen modes. No VSync, no Anti-Aliasing. Additionally, the game's internal renderer is locked to 720p, and the game won't output anything but 720p. Fullscreen on an 1080p screen will thus either stretch/scale accordingly, or add black bars.They have also failed to add audio options. There are no volume sliders at all.On the Gameplay front, there's enough been said already. The game is excruciatingly linear, and chock-full of cutscenes. For comparison: If you played Final Fantasy X and considered it too linear due to the lack of global world map and directly connected areas, you'll hate XIII. It takes a good 15-20 hours of corridor walking to reach the point where it opens up a little bit. There is little to nothing to distract you from narrow corridors.The combat system is shoving the Auto-Battle command down your throat right from the start. The command selects attacks and abilities based on dynamically calculated algorithms. Especially early on, where the characters are limited to one job, with one or two commands(!), the game turns into a simple "Press A to do stuff" simulator. The tactical element from previous Final Fantasy titles is almost completely lost as a result, as the game almost turns the player into a passive observer.On top of this, the game attempts to "rate" the player's combat performance from 1 to 5 stars, based on how long it took them to win a battle. The rating affects the item drops, but even then a 5 star rating will not guarantee even common drops. I'd also like to point out that the target time, especially early on, is very generous, almost giving double the time you actually need to finish a battle with a 5 star rating.Lastly, battles are completely isolated from one another. Where in previous FF titles you had to watch your HP carefully, and would take damage and negative status effects into the following battles, XIII instead heals the party to full health after a win. Wave-based engagements like seen in Final Fantasy X (most notably the tutorial section teaching you to pick targets wisely, or the Bevelle Marriage scene) do not stress you beyond the current, very short battle.As for the story I will just say it is very, very convoluted and throws technobabble at the player for lack of better writing. The characters contradict each other and themselves at every turn, and make you shake your head in disbelief. At least the Japanese Audio will make their voices bearable, though.Be prepared to read up on a lot of the game's terminology and background via the in-game Datalog to fully grasp the game's reasoning. Still, do not expect things to make complete sense.Graphically, it still looks quite nice, with pretty effects being thrown around. The vast amount of pre-rendered cutscenes (18, if I count the game's video files) look gorgeous, even if the contents aren't making for a good story. If you enjoy eyecandy, you will get it, even though the resolution lock and lack of options are a big failure on Square Enix's part.Overall, the pricetag reflects the game's quality. The mechanics and exploration are half-baked and too automated and controlled to satisfy an old franchise fan like me. The port is dreadful, and I would not recommend buying it until they at least offer a patch to add some basic settings for graphics and audio. If you can't wait, though, please don't expect it to be up there with the franchise's gems and fan-favorites. It "innovated" on all the wrong areas, and neglected its core vision as well as the franchise's strongest point: Storytelling and Character Development. As such, XIII is a lukewarm JRPG at best, and a below-average corridor crawler at worst.

Fantastic start to a trilogyPros:+ Great visuals+ Amazing story+ Great characters+ Lovely soundtrack+ Superb voice acting+ New decent combat system+ Beautiful game for screenshots+ Good character development throughout the storyNeutral Points:> Decent port but could of been better> Combat system is a hit and miss, some like it and some don't> Performance is also up and down, great for some and bad for others> Each character is better at something, less freedom of picking characters you like for the best partyCons:- FPS drops, common for many people - Forced characters with set roles for a lot of the game- Takes too long to be able to have freedom with your party- The game is very linear, added with the forced party for a lot of the game theres just not a lot of freedom till late in the gameDownload Size: 59395mbTrading cards: 6 in the set ( Quite costly these cards are)Achievement Difficulty: ModerateHours to 100%: 50-100Rating: 9/10Recommendation: A must buy for Final Fantasy lovers, screenshot lovers, rpg lovers or just for those who love a great storyMy opinion:An amazing game for many types of people and at a great price, tons of hours of entertainment to be had. I love the characters, the voice acting and the story. The combat is good in my eyes and is enjoyable, although I didn't like how there was little freedom in the game till much later on. Once you get far you have more freedom, but I still enjoyed the linear path up till then, seeing the characters go their own ways and develop. An absolutely amazing game for screenshots, and with the amount of hours it takes to complete you will get tons of great shots. For Final Fantasy lovers its another great game, I mean for those who love the franchise overall and not just the old games. It is also a great game for rpg lovers. Worth it at full price but it does go on sale now and then.

number of helpful: 83 of 148 people (56%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Until now I've never quit playing a Final Fantasy game in the entire franchise's history. I don't even hold the earlier series in nostalgic sacredness like so many. FF7 was not my favorite. I loved 3(6) as much as the core fans, but I loved 5 and even 12 especially. Wasn't a huge fan of 10, but 10-2 was a blast. I played 11 online for well over a year on my PS2 and even though it wasn't a "real' FF game made no difference to me. It something different yet familiar and I enjoyed it in it's time. Point is I've experienced the series and have my own personal expectations when it comes to ups and downs. Being "new" doesn't sway me from critiquing a game so hard. I'm not mad because this game wasn't 7.5 or 6 HD.  I'm mad because this game was the first FF game I've refused to finish due to sheer stupidity on the games behalf. I've heard it was bad, but really assumed people were just not accepting a few things and that I'd find some kind of joy in playing it. Sadly, I owe all of these people an apology.The game had some amazing ideas but it played out through the most time consuming nonsensical game flow I've ever seen. Final Fantasy games are usually top quality JRPG games, but this felt like something some B-label released on the  Vita as a niche experiment for marketing. Someone made a video game that 'They" wanted to play but they forgot about other people, and that's more than fantastic in the terms of selfish design. You should create experiences that mirror your own wants and needs, but you don't ruin a successful franchise to do it. The combat was actually a GOOD idea. Shifting into jobs and allowing other abilities to be used on the fly was forward thinking , but it's actually backwards in design. Monsters that have 89 million health so that you will consider the stagger meter at all times sounds tactical, but it's actually in-line with the rest of the game's thinking when it comes to cramming you down a corridor and forcing you to play a very specific way. Most of the fights boiled down to "create a few sets and find the right rotation" and once you did. It just became this treadmill of working your way through the same enemies over and over to get to the next key event. "But that's Final Fantasy!". Actually you'd be correct, but it's not as fun when you aren't dynamically creating CHARACTERS you feel confident in. You are more or less just leveling jobs. Since the system is based on time = reward and the mobs have so much health,  you eventually get to the point where you don't want to fight a group of mobs forever so you begin to forsake the tanky roles and get more risky with damage and the debuffer types. Hey so the system works right? No. I don't design a character I enjoy. I design a placeholder full of jobs that I leveled up to compliment other placeholder jobs. Then I put someone else in my party and I have to rearrange all of those sets again.  The fact that characters are kinda like Transformers in their abilities is cool, but to be honest it's just dumb to constantly rotate someone to cast Faith or Protect. You didn't stop a character from having the ability to be able to use a lot of skills from other jobs. You just put this weird gated system in that made it a puzzle game to get to the the spell you need. The game would have been 892949% better had I just picked which spells to give someone and limited the usage of them much like the older games, but ALSO a step towards something new and different reflected. You tried to reinvent the wheel here, but you put square wheels on an otherwise drivable car.Combined with the grindy "level up equipment" that's introduced some 15 hours into the game, and it's also nearly impossible make use of until AFTER the game opens up, Characters are only reflected in the cutscenes. Their abilities should actually define them. In the past we've had super memorable characters like Terra and Vivi that were a product of their abilties. Not placed on the screen as a mindless attitude between coming up with stupid combos of things for them to do whilst you fight on to the next cutscene. The game's image is saying Lightining is basically a Commando that runs around shoving her sword up everything's butt. In the actual GAME though she's great at casting spells and healing people, which is quite a contradiction to shoving a sword up someone's butt. Not to mention training her in said jobs was a pointlessly gated system of absolutely no-choice whatsoever. Hold the button, level the things up on this pretty screen. Beat a boss? You can do it some more!That said I hated this game. I really wanted to finish the story and give XIII-2 a chance since I already own it. I took a blind guess at how this game would end and a leap of faith into the interwebs. Wikipedia told me I was absoultely right in guessing the outcome because it's pretty to assume that every single established cliche would come into fruition (spoiler alert: it does!), so no I don't need to play this garbage for 30 more hours to feel satisfied nor justify my opinion that this is without a doubt one of the worst JRPG games I've ever played in the history of video games. It pains me to say that. This is a person that has done speedrun after speedrun of Final Fantasy 1 on the NES and tried crazy things like all White Mage parties. It's sad that the 1980's gave this level of flexibility and fun factor when it came to interacting with the game's mechanics and character choice. There is none of that here.  Pretty cutscenes cannot outweigh terrible game mechanics. Final verdict:3/10.This game is a corridor of linear failure that will annoy you if you expect to play an actual video game that tests something... anything... other than patience towards tedium and monotony. And this comes from a person that loves grindy JRPGS. (for Lolth's sake I played Marvel Heroes for almost 400 hours and that game is terribly grindy and admittingly boring! I couldn't stand to even finish this one)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
DISCLAIMER: I own the ASIA version of this game, which means I have played with Japanese audio and English subtitles.ReviewEven with its linear design, this game is quite enjoyable. Especially for me as it is my first ever Final Fantasy game. At the first part, it’s all fun and games. Most of the time, you just have to click the auto-battle and eventually, enemies will die. As I progress through, it really gets harder and harder. I had to bring out tons of different guides from the internet on how to upgrade efficiently, I had to search the internet for the best combinations and which weapon fits each character perfectly. In the last chapter, I ended up turning down the difficulty from normal mode to easy mode because enemies just became a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥The good part is definitely not at the start, which is probably the reason a person will just stop playing. You can clearly see this from the average playtime of the users over here[steamspy.com].  ProsGame Length – One of the things you can expect from any Final Fantasy game is how long it takes to finish the story alone. For whatever price you got this game, you will surely get your money’s worth. Characters – I think they are all amazingly done; they will definitely grow on you. They should… Given how long this game is.Skill system – Upon reaching a certain chapter, all characters can build up any class types. But ofcourse, different characters excel at different classes.Cutscenes – This is already given, you can always expect that Square Enix will leave you in awe.NeutralPlot – I believe that there is not a single game on the franchise wherein the storyline is bad. I think it all comes down to which one is better. XIII may not be ranked as the top ones, but it is still great. Battle System – It’s a kind of battle system that you either love it or hate it. The game uses Command Synergy Battle, you can learn more about that in this site[finalfantasy.wikia.com]. Basically, you only control 1 character while the other two will fight automatically. And an ATB gauge which is utilized for your commands. Region Locking – Apparently, if you live in Asia or atleast bought this game from Asia, you are bound to only have Japanese audio and English/Chinese/English subtitles. I understand that Japanese audio is the original, and nothing beats the original. But it wouldn’t hurt to have an option, right? Meanwhile those who don’t live in Asia will have both English and Japanese audio. The only downside of this, is that you will be downloading around 26gb more than those who live in Asia. ConsBad Optimization – It’s like they forgot that they are porting this game to PC. The game has very limited graphic options, four options to be exact: Screen Settings (Full-Screen or Windowed), Resolution, Shadow Resolution and Anti-aliasing (MSAA). Top those with a 30 FPS lock in-game and a 60 FPS lock on some cutscenes. Very Linear Gameplay – It says linear as one of its genre in the store page, but I did not expect a tutorial for about 40 hours wherein three guys walk a corridor and eventually get a taste of some side quests.

content:
Posted: February 18
												I've finally decided to play this game years after its release and it was a lot better than I was expecting after hearing it get dumped on over the last 8 years.The story is pretty average for a JRPG (in that bad writing, bad dialogue, but kinda charming type of way that most JRPS have). The characters were ok and I actually liked Lighting and Sazh, the only character I really disliked was Hope as I generally hate children characters and surprisingly Vanille grow on me from hate to indifference. Snow was also a♥♥♥♥♥♥character but not so bad that I hated him.I actually liked the combat more than most final fantasy games as it had me actually thinking a little more than your standard final fantasy game. Now, the game play was extremely linear and I can understand why people would dislike it. However, if you take a step back nearly all JRPS are linear games placed in an open worlds that are mostly empty, this game just gets rid of the empty world that I would normally ignore so I didn't have too many issues with it.Overall it's a pretty decent Final Fantasy game (nowhere near as good as 6 but still above average).Actual game aside, this port is full of technical issues and has horrible frame rate drops. The reason I don't play consoles is mostly due to the 30fps standard that most game have and this game hurt my head at times during the frame rate issues. If you cannot deal with 30fps or inconsistent frame rates do not buy this game.

number of helpful: 40 of 69 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIII has been a hot button issue for many fans of the series, and of RPGs in general.  It cuts a few of the archetypal role-playing elements, while adding little to make up for it.  It's linear, you're gonna be dealing with pre-made parties, tutorials, and little customization for about %70 of the main game.  Regardless of all that, I really enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII.  The combat is simple, yet fun and rewarding.  The game looks great, and the music and SFX are top notch, and even though the story and cast are a bit mediocre, it's still very much worth a play.Now, the big elephant in the room...Being locked at 720p isn't what most of us were hoping for, even if they did allow for 60fps.  I understand a lot of gamers are gonna be disappointed by this, but for me, Square Enix has delivered a product worth a buy from me.  The price is low, I have not experienced any bugs or glitches, and this could possibly open up a future of more Final Fantasy games on PC.Overall, good game, but not what a lot of people wanted out of a main Final Fantasy title, and a mediocre PC port at a low price point.

												Having a lot of hours and run throughs in the game, I would recommend this for anyone looking to play this Final Fantasy Game. Just not on this platform. Xbox go for it, Play Station go for it. The PC wasn't the original intention for this game to be played on. Most of the time I run it with around 30 fps. Whenever I get into a battle it drops frames and it's a lot more enjoyable with a controller. Though you could just connect a controller to your computer to play it. The story is really enjoyable although it is really linear which you just have to get used to. The next two Final Fantasy XIII's are not as linear as this one. The music is also really enjoyable with most other Final Fantasy Games. If you are going to finish this I would highly reccomend finishing the next two titles in the XIII Series. It's kind of funny cause all of the XIII games are considered three parts of one game but just sold seperately. Overall I would highly reccomend this game

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Square did right by attempting to remove the garbage filler from JRPGs, such as persistent health, MP, having to actually choose every battle command, having to control everyone, etc. It's really nice to see a company trying to fix outdated ideas. Unfortunately they took out so much that there isn't really a game left. It's just hallways, interspersed with rote battles and mind-numbing cut scenes. There's no exploration either, but sometimes the hallway you're in branches and allows you to fight some more enemies in exchange for a treasure chest. The characters are dull tropes and the dialogue is worse than a 4Kids dub. Even the leveling up system feels like it was pared down: it's like FFX's Sphere Grid, but lacking any kind of significant branching. I'm about 14 hours in, and the game is still feeding me a steady drip of new battle mechanics, each more tedious than the last; unfortunately, new mechanics don't make the game more fun or interesting, because battles are still essentially just blocks of time where you mash A for a while. I mean, sometimes the game throws you a single stronger enemy and you need to switch between preset battle styles, but in practice it feels more tedious than exciting or interesting. Battles aren't the only thing that's repetitive: the dialogue gets repeated and rephrased a lot too, so I frequently found myself watching two dimensional characters think out loud at each other over and over. Of the ~14 hours I've played, I think about half of it has been just watching cut scenes. Some of the sequences are so long there are (sometimes multiple) save points in the middle. Some of the sequences are so long that my Steam Link shuts off because it hasn't received any inputs in a long time.I want to like this game, and I feel like if I kept at it, by the time I got to the end the battles could be legitimately interesting. But I also feel like it'll still be dripping me new ideas right up to the final boss. I've kind of been playing this in the hopes that at some point, they say, "OK, tutorial over!" but, again, I'm at 14 hours and so far the game has only treated me like a moron and I'm just kind of tired of doing the same♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over to advance characters that I can't force myself to pay attention to.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												As a 2nd playthrough of this game as i played it on PlayStation on it's original release back in 2010, I have really come to appreciate Final Fantasy XIII.Final Fantasy XIII is the 13th main entry in the Final Fantasy Series, and was realeased for PS3 and Xbox 360 in Japan in 2009. It follows the story of Lighting and her comrads who are branded enemies of Coccon, there own home planet.  Together, they overcome their troubles and help save Coccon from eniemes and it's corrupt politics.Pros- Battle/Combat system is great, I believe it was done nicely and is a great transition from its previous iterations.- Great Music; the orchestrated music fits in beautifully throughout the game. - Some Lovable and relatable characters; But some people might find the main protagnist, Lighting to be boring. - Provides hours of gameplay and end-game side quests. - Graphics, Art Style and CGI Cutscenes are beautiful, they blew me away when i first played the game.Cons - Grinding. I mean, heaps of Grinding. The Boss fights in this game can be extremeley difficult if you do not level up and upgrade your characters correctly through the game. - Confusing Story. The story is completely all over the place, as there is too much happening all at once and is to much to understand. It took me 2 playthroughs to understand the game's story fully. - Not too well optimised on PC, and lack of graphics options.Other than that, I believe Final Fantasy XIII is a pretty solid entry in the Final Fantasy Series, but I do not recommend it if you are new to the Franchise and want to start off with this game, I'd rather recomend Final Fantasy 10 if you are a newcomer.

												Final Fantasy 13 is the most recent installment in the series to be released for PC.While a controversial game, for many reasons such as it's inability to disguise a mainly linear game and 20-hour long tutorial it also holds ground with a deep combat system that's easy to learn, lifetime to master.The games follows 6 humans turned into l'Cie, servants of fal'Cie(gods of sorts) to do their bidding and destroy Cocoon. The story picks up immediately into a conflict and throws you straight into action, albeit you mash your mouse button for a while before things get interesting.Provided you beat the gruelling tutorial-hallway, you are rewarded with an extensive world to explore freely with numerous sidequests and great scenery to accompany it.PROS[] Great Soundtrack[] Massive end-game[] Fantastic storyline[] Very deep combat systemCONS[] Linear for a fair amount of time[] A few main characters are pains in the butt[] Squeenix limited it to 720p for some reasonAll in all, I'd say if you are willing to try a game that has a bit of a slow start, you are rewarded with a great storyline, a deep combat system and a fantastic story!8/10 Great game.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												For the past year I avoided this game like a plague, seeing that most reviews were either bad or ridiculously bad. Finally after giving it the pass for so many times (it's summer sales anyway), I finally bought this copy and gave it a try.I'm a total idiot. I've just realised:1.  I've missed this game all for naught for the past 2 years.2.  Whomever wrote all those junk review, do you even FF?  Linear? Boring? Really? 3.  I'm not going to take reviews seriously anymore.  Especially on FF titles.On the bright side, I have you *********s to thank for, since I have the whole trilogy to binge through this year!Update 25 July 2016:The first 10 chapters is akin to an interactive story, where you're guided through the background story and character development.  The pace is slower than previous FF titles, but it also paces the player into gradually learning the game's system.  You will notice that there are more and more things to fiddle with as you progress into the game.  It won't take long before you find yourself into the routine of building up stats, leveling up weapons, running from point A to point B, and tapping the 'ok' button through every battle.  You will hate it if:You're looking for more challenge and control over the story line from Chapters 1 - 10.  However, you will still get to develop your characters and weapons.  Boss fights are surprisingly challenging.  You will like it if:You're here for the JRPG element of FF series - particularly the storyline.  You will realise that considerable effort has been invested into this aspect, at the risk of oversimplifying interaction at the player's part.  Nevertheless, I enjoy sitting back with a 6-pack of ice-cold beer after a hard day's work, hitting the same button while looking at the battle scenes. Doesn't tax the brain too much but gives just the right amount of entertainment. Oh and did I mention that sight seeing it great too, it's like Skyrim except you don't get to jump off the cliff.You will find a significant change of experience on Chapter 11, where you are presented with a sizeable 'open' map, and the freedom to complete missions at will.  Will update my impression again once I clock more hours into the game.A must-know before you decide NOT to buy:A lot of critics (starting the raging bitter ones) compare FFXIII with other FF titles. This is probably what stopped a lot of genuine buyers from buying this title, myself included. While most arguments are valid, being judged as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ compared to other FF titles doesn't make it ♥♥♥♥♥♥ compared to all other games available on Steam.  If you're into JRPG and don't hate FF games in general, chances are you're happier buying and playing this than some other random title on Steam.Tl;dr1. FFXIII is not bad enough to give it a pass - still better than a lot of other games2. Not a great choice if you're in for a challenge from the onset3. Great choice if you're in for a relaxing, therapeutic story-telling jrpg experience

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												This is my first JRPG and I liked it. It was different from any other games I've played. Its combat system is quite different. In western RPGs such as Witcher 3, battle is real time. You can explore and then get into a battle with someone and then fight and win and go back to exploring, or can even run away in the middle of a fight and go back to exploration seamlessly. But in this game, you explore and then when you get into a fight with someone, you enter the battle mode, which is totally different from exploration. You can't run away in the middle of a battle. It will go on until the fight ends. Exploration in this game is very limited. It has been called a corridor simulator for good reasons, but it's not necessarily a bad thing. Some of the environments are quite beautiful, but it's mostly look-but-don't-touch. Battle is somewhat turn based, but not exactly. In turned based games or game modes you wait for your turn. But instead of waiting for your turn, in the battles of this game, you wait for something called your ATB meter to fill up. When it fills up, you can fight, which consumes your meter. So again you wait for it to fill up and then fight. That's a very simplistic explanation because the battle system of this game has quite a bit of depth to it and I really enjoyed it. It was refreshing. When it comes to role-playing, the thing that stands out most from western RPGs is that you can play multiple roles at the same time. And you can change between those roles within an on going battle. For example one offensive role is called Commando and you do mostly physical damage with it. But then if you developed your character as a medic, you can switch to that role mid battle and you can heal yourself and your allies and once done, you can switch back to Commando. I was enjoying the game till Chapter 11. But Chapter 12 and Chapter 13 were dull and frustrating. There is no story progressoin. They filled the last two chapters of the game with bosses. Even some other enemies were so tough they felt like bosses. It kind of left a bad taste in my mouth. But don't get me wrong, I am still glad I played it because up to Chapter 11 the game is quite fun. The final story progression is after the final boss battle. So they could have removed chapter 12 and chapter 13 completely, and just put the final boss battle at the end of chapter 11. It would have been a much better game. I am glad I finished it and I recommend it. It's a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												THE GAME:What I once regarded as my least favorite Final Fantasy game by far, and one of my least favorite games ever, has somehow grown on me quite a bit given a lot more time. To get the negatives out of the way, the bulk of the game, especially the critical path, is extremely linear, sometimes even resembling series of interconnected hallways with battles scattered along the way. That said, there is a very rewarding wealth of late-game content awaiting those who can persevere. A huge number of optional side quests and expansive, wide-open areas, in stark contrast to the former half to two thirds of the game. However, as I found out, it is very much worth the wait. And the real core of the experience, and what drove me to keep going to the end (and then some), is the excellent combat system. The battle system is fairly unconventional for a FF game, while still drawing a lot of inspiration from the previous entries, giving a sense of familiarity to series fans, while also making it feel very fresh and different. This difference is something that you may love or hate. Yes, there is a lot of "mash A to win" in the combat here, but once the game finally allows you to experience all of what the combat system has to offer, you'll understand that the addition of an "auto battle" menu option in battle doesn't actually dumb down or simplify the tried and true Final Fantasy combat, but instead shifts the tactical focus to clever use of the "paradigm shift" mechanic at the right times to dole out the damage, buff/debuff, heal, etc. What this ultimately means is FFXIII offers as much tactical potential in its combat as the previous games in the series, while making it feel much faster-paced and intense. It is extremely unfortunate that the game forcibly holds your hand for nearly 10 hours before finally letting you really get an idea of what this combat can offer, and another 15-20 hours on top of that to really let you go nuts with it, but if you can stick it out, you will be rewarded greatly.Visually, the game is still incredible looking, regardless of the fact that it came out nearly 5 years ago. The music is excellent as well, almost across the board, as is usually the case with the Final Fantasy series. As for the story and characters, it's a mixed bag, and definitely something that will differ based on personal tastes. For me, I didn't find much substance in either. There are certainly some flashy moments here and there, but I mainly looked forward to getting back to combat any time a cutscene popped up.THE PORT:Now, just like the game is a bit of a mixed bag, the same goes for this PC port. It's pretty obvious that there wasn't a ton of effert put into sprucing the game up for it's PC debut: a complete lack of graphical options, resolution that is locked to 1280x720, plenty of performance issues varying from user to user, and a MASSIVE download size weighing in at about 50 gigabytes. It's far from a polished release, for sure. That being said, it's also a relatively inexpensive release, at a regular $15 at the time of this writing, and for that price and the amount of time I've been able to put into it so far, I can look past the few crashes and occasional framerate hiccups (or chokes, at times), and be pretty happy with the purchase. And if they manage to patch the game up and improve performance, then all the better.TLDR:The game has an amazing combat system hidden under a soso story and HOURS of linear, handholding gameplay, but the wait is well worth it. The PC port is also pretty iffy, but if you can look past the performance flaws, you'll have a good time with it for the price.

												Lets take a minute to consider this, ignoring the port, ignoring how awfully Square Enix botched the Job on the PC version and lets take a look the game for a second and ask ourselves a single question: Is Final Fantasy XIII bad?NO IT'S NOT! I don't understand the hate towards this game, i understand that it has awful flaws. The cosntant tunnel runs being the main gripe, but gameplay wise is it bad? No! the combat system is actually interesting, the issue with it is that it isn't fully realized, they had an idea but they didn't fully execute a team wide combat system for some reason, but despite that its still a very fun and interesting combat system. As for the story, it isn't as conveluted as most people might think, the main problem here is that the names of the "Deities" are largely similar to what the Human Drones and "Branded" humans are, but despite that the backstory is actually quite unqiue! I love the world buliding, the locations, the general universe and its all quite exciting if you think about it. The main downfall storywise is the likability of the characters; Snow is overly passionate, Hope is all a bit too whiney at the beginning before gaining his Edulon, Vanille always seems like an awkward mix of Postitive and Depressed. but I feel like most of the issue here is fixed through the Japanese Voice Acting, because they deliver the lines much more genuinely than the English counterparts that go full ham and not enough ability to tone it down! Besides what I see as the worst game in the Franchise - Final Fantasy VIII - comparitively its so much better, but I still see hoards of people give VIII a glowing score beause ♥♥♥♥ing nostalgia! but its not much different to Final Fantasy X as a game now is it? I mean they're similar yet they both are hold in different acclaim and I think there is a reason.Endless Corridors. Check. A plotline involving the destruction of a civilization through the transformation into said destructive force (Ragnarok and SIN). Check.  Character with a Shadey past and Moody demeanor (Lightning/Auron). Check. Token happy Ethnic guy with troubled past (Sazh/Wakka). Check. Scared healer needing the support of everyone who finds their feet (Yuna/Hope). Check. Its scary how similar the two games and I think thats partially the reason. but I feel like the main hate of this game is beacuse Square are realizing Final Fantasy is the same game year after year, and they've wanted to change that since XII/Kingdom Hearts. So this was the first step in an entirely new direction. They want to keep the old souls happy, so they made Bravely Default, but they've come to realise that Final Fantasy can't be the same game anymore, they want it to be more of a cinematic experience. Final Fantasy XV looks like the prime example of that.edit: The PC version suffered from awful porting with no graphics options. They somehow vamped up the graphics so much that when it turned it on after the update I literally♥♥♥♥♥♥myself after seeing the difference. it looks so. much. ♥♥♥♥ing. better. than. the. console. counterparts.Literally 8/10 right now.Square enix are seeing the PC market as a serious money maker and they seem to care right now. this is only a good thing

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Having being very familiar with the PS3 version of FINAL FANTASY XIII, I feel pretty confident to write this review for the Steam version, thus why my playtime may not seem that high.(And judging by some of your comments, I am aware that there are some graphical issues currently surrounding the port)FINAL FANTASY XIII is not a bad game. Honestly, it’s not. Not as bad as everyone says anyway. As far as story goes, it’s pretty much the same old Final Fantasy formula. A group of unsuspecting heroes must travel to the farthest reaches of the world in order to destroy an ancient evil which hangs the very fate of the world in the balance. However, FINAL FANTASY XIII (referred to as FF XIII from now on) has probably one of the most convoluted narratives I have ever come across, which needed three games in order to straighten out (and even then they didn’t do all that great a job.) FF XIII is an epic adventure, and is successful in managing to make its self interesting and is sure to hook your attention for the 40-50 hours you will be spending there. However, the game does take a while to get off. Things start to get interesting around hours 10-20, where the pacing begins to move the game more steadily. The story is told from the perspectives of our new playable heroes; Lighting, Snow, Hope, Sazh, Fang and Vanille. These characters have been subject to a lot of criticism, which is understandable because most of them are extremely unlikable and far too whacky for their own good. They fit well in to the story however, and that’s probably the only thing that makes them bearable.  The gameplay is probably one of the better aspects of the game, as the new Paradigm System is a huge improvement on previous Final Fantasy battle systems. It allows complete customisation of the battle field and characters, as the new level-up system allows you to level up certain aspects of your characters. As far as a Final Fantasy game goes, this really does break the chain and dares to be different. As the first FF game to grace the 7th console generation, it tried to be something new and I think it succeeded in doing so. It is a very enjoyable game, despite its many flaws – and is easily the best game in the FINAL FANTASY XIII trilogy. It’s whacky, it’s new and it’s different. But sadly, I think it can only be enjoyed fully by a fan of the series. If you are looking to join the Final Fantasy universe, do not start with this one. Try out FINAL FANTASY VII, and see how you feel from there.All in all, FINAL FANTASY XIII does not deserve the criticism it gets. It’s not the best Final Fantasy, nor is it the worst. If you decide to give this game a bash, then you DON’T need to play FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 and Lighting Returns to get the full story. They essentially tarnish the narrative in FF XIII, so only get in to the trilogy if you are ready for a commitment. + Great battle system, one of the best that the series has to offer+ Story is told in an interesting way. Characters interact well with each other and the narrative + Level up system- Convoluted narrative. Made worse by unnecessary sequels- Poor pacing. Game takes  a while to kick off- Bad port- Over powered bosses. What else did you expect? It’s Final Fantasy 8/10

content:
Posted: January 3
												A streamlined jRPG that emphasizes plot and stylish combat over the tedium of towns and most of the micro-management. About the only thing left on the latter front is the weapons upgrading, which you can take if you're into it, use a guide to get it out of the way or, so I hear, ignore entirely.Speaking of plot, it can be a little convoluted and certainly is a lot to take in at first but not to worry, everything will be explained eventually. Often slated for very linear game progression, this game design decision at the very least does its best to help you follow the story instead of having you search for it. Still, there's secrets and the occasional time and place for grinding and side quests if you so choose.The semi-automatic battle system, aside from being where it's at, takes a little while to get used to. Instead of might-as-well-be-action-game real-time gameplay and the contemplatetiveness of a full-on turn based system, you get an interesting mix of both. First you take your time and plan ahead before battle setting up team formations and then during one, you're fully engaged managing them letting your team play out their assigned roles while reserving the right to more direct control of your party leader.Audiovisually, the game's got that Squeenix Seal of Quality stamped on it, although some locale and feral creature designs are a bit too gaudy for my liking. Voice acting, for the most part, is alright. Same goes for the characters portrayed but fortunately you can bench the ones you like the least later in the game. Still I wish the entire entourage was visible while travelling, not just the selected battle team.Technically the game has a some performance issues which can be mostly dealt with guides. With that done, the game plays beautifully with a controller and streams flawlessy to your TV over the Steam Link.Some helpful links:http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Final_Fantasy_XIIIhttp://www.beforeiplay.com/index.php?title=Final_Fantasy_13

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
I LOVE Final Fantasy XIII, I am an ardent defender of the game itself. This port however doesn't do it justice. Game has been patched, but the patch is pretty much a joke. It essentially just does was GeDoSaTo did. And ended up creating a few more problems in the process like FMVs now stutteringList of issues currently remainingLow volume. The game currently has about 20dBfs worth of headroom until it hits the noise ceiling of -0.0dBfsNo volume slider. People could balance the audio to their taste or turn off thingsPoor performance during battle and FMVsMicrostuttering when playing above 30FPS.Let's look at this graph http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/ae5Untitled1.jpgThe top line is Framerate and the bottom is frame time.This sample was taken over the course of 60seconds of gameplay in and out of battles with a polling rate of 16ms (a game running at 60FPS SHOULD spit out frames every ~16.67ms or so. When it doesn't, the result is microstuttering or what is commonly known now as "Frame pacing issues")(Ignore the drops down to 0 as that is normal with a fast polling rate)  You will want to notice however, the lines between those gaps. This should be a flat line like this http://u.cubeupload.com/MrBonk/wcap.jpg So in battle, the game is constantly spiking frames upwards of 33ms. Causing the game to stutter and drop frames.  No stable framerate caps available. See the above. Need 30FPS,60FPS and unlocked frame caps. You can stabilize performance by using a 30FPS cap and 1/2 refresh rate Vsync. But that doesn't do anything for 60FPS.Sub-par low resolution ultra compressed Bink FMVs60GB DL FOR THE ABOVE VIDEOS. Because game includes both JPN and ENG FMVs instead of smartly offering different versions to download or as free DLCYou'd think they'd have a clue already since their Europe/NA branch is so prolific on PC as it is.Square Enix should offer several builds to downloadlower quality FMVs - Englishlower quality FMVs - JapanesePS3 quality FMVs - EnglishPS3 quality FMVs - JapaneseWith some proper effort, SE could've killed this port.
