content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Opinions on FF XIII are either strongly for or strongly against.I fall under the former category.In short I strongly recommend this game to all fans of jRPGs, those who do not put freedom of exploration before the story and are alright with being steered by the narrative instead of shaping it. The story is only hard to understand if you are unwilling to read the additional information provided in the codex which offers further explanation, but if you spend some additional time reading it, I believe you'll find it quite enjoyable. It is a tale of coming to terms with one's circumstances, challenging onself and then facing a seemingly hopless situation head on and learning the machination behind what might seem a random plot at a glance. Detailed reviewStoryNarrative is placed in a world that is a mixture of sci-fi and fantasy, focused on the struggle of each of the 6 main characters learning to deal with the situation they have been thrown into and their growth into people which will try to change their fate however improbable the odds may be. It is set in a time of unexpected war and starts off by throwing the player into the middle of the things, ensuring the player is as every bit as confused with the entire situation as the protagonists  are. While the story unfolds, it offers some additional insight into the protagonists minds by means of flashbacks mixed with some read-through material in the form of a codex. It is also being told for the majority of the game through the points of view of the specific characters until, quite late in the game, it gets unified into one generic point of view of all the characters joined together in one goal. The initial pace the story unfolds in is slow, however, mixed with a sort of prolonged introduction into the battle system. It picks up the pace after around 7-8 hours into the story.MusicHands down one of my favorite OST ever created for a video game. Love it, is all I am going to say.GameplayI find this game to be beautiful, with detailed settings, interesting character design, but not something you would not expect in a jRPG, and interesting monsters design. All is kept in a clearly defined style which adds to the story as one can see everything is a part of the same universe. Nothing in this game seems out of place.The battle system is sort of turn based with its own twist, but it really takes its time to give the player full control.I agree that the tutorial is way too long for no apparent reason, limiting the player choices to very few options in the early game. The introduction of class switching and the intricacies of this system are explained and then make for some very spectacular and interesting battles, but I do feel it has been weirdly dumbed down in its execution. The complexity of this system and the need to really plan one's tactics comes up in only a couple of battles.The entire game can be beaten quite fast, but in order to complete all of the side quests, all of which involve running somewhere and killing a monster, and get all of the achievements griding for experience becomes necessary and quite tedious. Especially since the sidequests are not really that creative and forcing player into a lot of running through all of the locations only for the sake of prolonging the time the player spends with this game.Thankfully the beauty of the game somewhat makes up for the need to revisit the locations and the amount of running one's does, nonetheless, I could have done without it and would have still loved the game.If you want to obtain all of the achievements you're looking into around 80 to 100 hours, depending on how willing you are to truly understand the mechanics of the battle system to ensure you can beat the most difficult enemies to receive the most experience points.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												XIII doesn't deserve all the bad reputation it received, just some of it.Story and characters are on the bad side in the series and game is pretty much one single linear path until like 15 hours into the game, at which point you can branch off a bit to do stuff. Combat system is new and fresh, but can be absolutely frustrating sometimes and game implements some questionable mechanics (like a lot of normal mobs can 1 shot entire party without sentinel) just to make it work. You also control only 1 character's combat directly, with even less freedom to customize other members' actions compared to XII. Equipment system is IMO ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and character progression is a linear path disguised in a convoluted spiral-grid-abomination thingy just to make you think you have choices (you don't).Graphically this game is about what you'd expect from FF port, console quality with some few improvements. All in all the port is quite lazy, everything is just pulled over to PC as is. It's fine though, as most will play this with a controller probably anyway. Fixing the instant esc quitting was a nice thing too.So, after ranting about all the bad and irrelevant sides of the game, why did I give it a thumbs up? It's still an interesting game, world looks great, I liked monster and boss designs, and combat, once you get used to it, can be really fun. XIII also refreshingly hard Final Fantasy unless you grind your♥♥♥♥♥off. Still, it's only barely thumbs up. It's not expensive considering how long game you get for this amount, and it's not all bad either, so you probably should at least give XIII a shot if you like JRPGs.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												First of all - i was playing at least 70 hours, as people can see the screenshots i took - BUT i was playing while was in offline mode and then came the first patch. steam has overwritten my savegame with a savegame that was uploaded in the cloud and threw me back about 52 hours, back to chapter 4. that sucked.knowing that this was still a poor worked-over port, i used the GeDoSaTo tool from Durante to unsure i had full-hd graphics with more or less 40-60 fps (people have to get to know their PC better before shouting that they have such a high-end setup that doesnt work), the tool works wonderful with the game and makes it a better experience as on the console. without, the game has overall performance difficulties, reason for that is most likely the fixed resolution of 720p at 24Hz (or something like that). therefore the game and the system has unnecessary extra work, that heavily slows down the game.i'm eager for the december 2014 patch for this game to see if SE can bring the game to a performance that is rather standard for most games released today.i will keep my opinion about the story to myself, except that you have to play all 3 FF XIII titles to get the full FF experience, i'll wait for that till i'll played all 3 here on steam (have played all three on the console)as for gameplay - i am fond of it, because it gives the hardcore FF-fan the chance for nice strategic battles and weapon customizations later in the game, while giving new players the platform to play a FF title without getting too deep into the FF mechanics which turns out unforgiving every once and a while.i highly recommend this title to all, who wants to play a FF, but dont want to spend an additional 100+ hours on sidequesting, farming, revealing story-related secrets, etc. BUT i would wait till SquareEnix has patched it properly, otherwise the easy to use GeDoSaTo tool is free for download (and if possible support Durante's great work!)

												I like this game; its got a great battle system and the soundtrack is nearly flawless. I'm only 15 hours into the game but so far the story is pretty captivating.my biggest beef with the game is that its pretty linear, but its no where near as bad as FF4. the graphics are amazing, especially for a game made in 2009! Most of the environments are breathtaking and very well designed.The characters have flaws and traits that are both likable and dislikeable, you'll have favourites and ones that you dont like as much, but overall, pretty well written characters. I got this game for $8 on sale and its was well worth it. if you're on the fence about the game i suggest buying it on sale. I actually prefer this to some of the earlier games like FF4 and FF10. 15 hours in and I'm not bored at all, FF13 starts slow, but if you give it time it really grows on you.I think this game is fun, dont listen to people who whine about the story, they are the reason FF Legends was made.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Having played this game on Xbox 360, I can say I am happy to own it on PC now as well. I thoroughly enjoyed the game and I don't undertand what is so confusing about the story to people. At this point, I think it is just a fad to call this story confusing. Sure some of the charatcers seem a little flat and aren't lovable, but they grow on you in different ways. Definitely by far, Hope has the most character development and becomes one of my favorites story-wise by the end of the game. Enough about the story though, let's talk about the port. So far (Although I haven't played it much yet) I have not run into a single bug, runs just as smooth as you would expect from a Square Enix game. the 60fps is definitely noticable having played it at a now considerably less smooth 30fps on console. The anti-aliasing is also a great touch going all the way up to 16x to wipe away the jaggies that 7th gen console games are known for. Having not actually changed the textures of the game (which still look fine for 2014), don't worry about raising the settings and experiencing lag because as long as you meet the recommended, pump up that AA. The shadows resolution goes all the way up to 8k creating crisp player shadows suring fights and walking around. And last but not least, being able to run this game natively 1080p is a dream come true. Given the astonishing beauty of this game even on console, a 1080p version of it makes it all the better and really turns this game into a piece of art. Now as for cons, just wish that they would have tweaked the gameplay just a bit like the camera control which is still god-awful. All it wants to do is reset back to center. Might as well have a fixed camera. I would have liked better camera control to admire the beautiful scenery this game has to offer. Also speeding up the gameplay such as making paradigm shifts smoother like in XIII-2 would have been nice. Instead you have the long drawn-out shifts. Also I would have liked to see them up the amount of Gil you get from treasure chests or maybe throw in Gil when you win a battle. Gil shortage was a huge problem in the console version and required endless hours of Trapezohedron and Plat ingot hunting to get enough to get everyone's final weapons. On console, I put about 120 hrs into a single playthrough of this game and probably more than 20 of it was grinding for money... This game was obviously a copy and paste port, but at the price point, can't blame them.Given there are no bugs so far and the game looks better and plays just as well as on console, I give the port a 9/10 and the game a 8/10. For a final fantasy game story wise, 7.5/10. My RIGi5-3570K 3.5GHz Quad8GB RAMGIGABYTE GTX 770 2GB OC Edition120GB SSD (only for Windows launch though)2TB Hard Drive for storageASRock Extreme3 MoBo

												Let me say this: You had better turn on the Japanese voices before you play this game.With that taken care of it makes the story more engaging (imho).Pros1. COMBAT. IS. SUPERB.2. The visual syle is very much Final Fantasy3. Soundtrack is beautiful to listen to4. Character development and interaction5. Stunning set pieces6. Combat animations. The way the characters fight in battle is how I imagined FF should be in my head while I was growing up.8. Ability to upgrade every weapon and accessory in the game7. Sazh. Most interesting character and extremely useful in battleCons1. ......VANILLE2. Mostly linear (But I don't hear people complaining about FFX's linearity?!!!! Cut this game some slack)3. 50GB download (C'mon, guys. Really?)4. Crystarium is limited by story progressionReally the main thing I loathe about this game are the English voices for Vanille (that's the woman's real voice, btw. Some kind of Australian/British/American thing she has going on. Absolutely horrendous), Snow (Even though he is a good voice actor I don't like how he portrayed this character), and Hope. Just......look, no one cares, Hope. Shutup.I am enjoying my second playthrough and picking up on things that I missed the first time around.I had forgot about Sazh's son, Dajh, being a Cocoon l'cie while Sazh is a Pule l'cie. Dem feelsI would recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of JRPGs and FF in general.

												Okay, first of all all I did not like that the game came with such a poor resolution by defualt, but after installing a third party tool, this game shined once again for me. The graphics turn amazing and I was again surprised as I was when this game came out and played it on PS3. This game in much more linear than most of other FF in the game series and the first installment n the series of FF XIII has a slow start, but later on the game becomes really fun. I totally support this game, specially if this mean square enix will bring other RPGs to PC. I have read so many complains about the graphics or the escape issue but really, is nothing that big. As a PC gamer I hardly press escape by mistake. This game is not perfect by far, but supporting it will show the industry it should release this games on PC too.  I will definitely recommend it to any RPG fan and I cannot wait to get the other 2 parts of the series. If SE bring FF XII to PC it will blow my mind!! EDIT: After playing the game a lot and been grinding in chapter 11 like crazy, I can say the game is as good as I remembered. I know it wont beat classics from SE but having on PC, the game looks amazing. The audio is spectacular, I have a 7.1 system, which I used on my PS3 as well and I do not remember the audio sound this clear. The sorround effects are great. I really recommend this game. I just hope we could get ports of the new HD version of FF-X/X-2.  But if SE realice how much more they can sell on Steam, I know they will make them available.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												The game itself is not bad. I played it on PS3 way back when. However, this game has so many problems on pc! This game only uses one core of your cpu making the framerate drop seemingly out of nowhere. It runs at 720p natively and you can't change it. It has no graphics options to speak of. It has no audio options to speak of. And on top of all that, if you just so happen to have an amd cpu the game sill be locked at 30 fps. To everyone thinking about buying this: DON'T! At least not until they patch it. If you really want the game but don't want to deal with any of this there is a petition to get Square to fix the game.Go here and sign the petition: http://www.change.org/p/final-fantasy-13-pc-version-1920x1080-and-graphic-options-give-the-pc-version-of-final-fantasy-13-the-ability-to-change-graphical-settingsPS: The reason why the game is a 50 gig download is because they automatically include the japanese audio. You don't even have a choice to download it!PPS: There is no real way to quit the game in ANY menu. You literally have to hit escape and the game instantly stops. No " Are you sure you want to quit?" It just ends!

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												'Warning, this person is a ff-fanboy for more than 13 years.'First of all after FF XII disaster, this game is like a savior to the FF-Universe. Some people might dislike it,  cause it starts as a linear play-style like FF X but I would say , there is nothing bad about it. Story might look complicate it to you with weird words and stuff that happens in the game, but with flashbacks and in-game dialogs between protagonists you'll likely begin to understand whats happening and like the scenario.Combat is different, different then what I've seen before. Characters have different roles which you can swap during combat to heal, make your enemies vulnerable or to create tactics which suits you best. Character development is quite same as FF X, in which you use points that you gained combat to increase their base stats and make them learn new spells and techniques. While the stories moves on , you meet with your Espers, like Shiva and Odin but the with the name of Eidolon, which you can use in-combat also. I don't know why, but they can turn into motorbikes and horses and stuff , I don't know why, but hey it's Final Fantasy Right?! And, even if it's a port from PS3, I am playing and also recording the game with 60 fps. Splendid work from Square-Enix.What I don't like about the game, is mostly the male main characters and first chapter areas of the game. I don't like Sazh, Snow and dark & wasteland areas, which you encounter a lot during first 6 chapters. On the other hand, female characters are awesome, which I can say, is the best in all of FF series. ( even better than Tifa or Terra in my opinion ) They are tough, cold but strong and have their own dark/painfull past which makes them more interesting and wealthy.With it's price, I asure you, you wont regret playing this game , but beware, 40gb's are gonna be downloaded first.10/10 will play again and make Lightning mai waifu. Sorry Fang..

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I liked the overall game. The graphics were nice and gameplay wasn't that complicated. This game took me a lot longer to finish than I had originally anticipated. It took me about 73ish hours to finish this game which I did not enjoy. Frankly it was too long for me. I don't understand why people would describe this game as "linear." When I played it, it did not feel very linear. They're a lot of side quests, lots of stuff you can find if you want, and lots of challenges that you can face if you want and of course there was a lot of grinding. I even got lost a few times wondering "ok, what am I suppose to be doing now?" The crysterium system (or however it's spelled) was probably one of the most infurating things I've encountered. I would constantly grind to max it out only to find out a few scenes later it would grow even bigger. I've had many moments while playing this game where I've said to myself "ok this has got to be the end or I'm really close to finishing this game" and I was way off. Let me give you a tip, when you're leveling the crysterium don't put any points in any other roles except the default ones given to the characters from the very begining. Save your points so once you reach level 5 (which is after you finish the game) and max out their main roles then you can start grinding for points in the other roles which aren't really neccessary and you'll probably won't use for some steam achievement or something. Oh and if you stuck on a mission that seems impossible, chances are it is. There are acouple of missions that are almost impossible to beat until after you finish the game so don't think it's because you didn't max the other not main roles, the game was simply made that way. I also found out while playing the game that the upgrading system is useless. You can finish this game without leveling your equipment at all. Save everything until after you finish the game then you can upgrade your equipment and try to unlock all of the things for a steam achievement or something. One last thing, this game is very buggy. It microstudders for me unless I use a 360 controller (or just a game controller) which is weird. This game is really poorly optimized for the PC. The FPS drops many times throughout the game. Even with the buggy FPS I still played this game and found some enjoyment out of it but it sucks that this game is optimized so poorly on the PC. I'm not going to recommend this game but I'm also not -not going to recommend this game, I leave that up to you. Since steam doesn't have a button other than yes or no I'll put a yes on it.

												The Story and Cinematics are awesome as always, however I was kinda dissapointed in the gameplay. If you expect a similar gameplay as in FF XII then you gonna get dissapointed. The Gambit system doesnt exist and the only thing you do is changing between predefined fighting stances (fighter, tank, mage, buffer, debuffer, healer) and press "Auto" to wait for your chars to end the battle. You also run in a straight line (which was probably said a billion times before) so the open world feeling as in FF XII is also non-existant.I won't tell anyone not to buy the game, because in the end the story was what kept me playing and you might love it as well.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												First of all - i was playing at least 70 hours, as people can see the screenshots i took - BUT i was playing while was in offline mode and then came the first patch. steam has overwritten my savegame with a savegame that was uploaded in the cloud and threw me back about 52 hours, back to chapter 4. that sucked.knowing that this was still a poor worked-over port, i used the GeDoSaTo tool from Durante to unsure i had full-hd graphics with more or less 40-60 fps (people have to get to know their PC better before shouting that they have such a high-end setup that doesnt work), the tool works wonderful with the game and makes it a better experience as on the console. without, the game has overall performance difficulties, reason for that is most likely the fixed resolution of 720p at 24Hz (or something like that). therefore the game and the system has unnecessary extra work, that heavily slows down the game.i'm eager for the december 2014 patch for this game to see if SE can bring the game to a performance that is rather standard for most games released today.i will keep my opinion about the story to myself, except that you have to play all 3 FF XIII titles to get the full FF experience, i'll wait for that till i'll played all 3 here on steam (have played all three on the console)as for gameplay - i am fond of it, because it gives the hardcore FF-fan the chance for nice strategic battles and weapon customizations later in the game, while giving new players the platform to play a FF title without getting too deep into the FF mechanics which turns out unforgiving every once and a while.i highly recommend this title to all, who wants to play a FF, but dont want to spend an additional 100+ hours on sidequesting, farming, revealing story-related secrets, etc. BUT i would wait till SquareEnix has patched it properly, otherwise the easy to use GeDoSaTo tool is free for download (and if possible support Durante's great work!)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
FF XIII is not a "traditional" Final Fantasy game in the sense that it places the story front and center for the vast majority of the game. This is different than other FF games in that the battle systems, mini-games, character abilities, and exploration are primarily hands-off affairs for the first 15+ hours. Once that period is over, there is a rich game to explore and delve into, but it takes time and not everyone will be up for the investment it takes to get there.Here's the breakdown section by section:StoryThe majority of the story in FF XIII happens between the characters that you control and the group of seemingly antagonistic entities known as Fal'Cie. There is quite a bit that happens that would take far too long to detail, but know that this is a pretty story-rich game with decent character development and a satisfying story arc for each character. That said, there isn't a lot of explanation of the backstory for the world, the Fal'Cie, and environments that happens in-game, which leaves the player with questions. There is much, much more information that can be gained by reading the datalogs in the menu, but it can be quite tedious and it's a shame that there wasn't more of this information put in the actual game. Clearly this game asks for a large amount of time from the player, would it have been that much more onerous to explain the inner-workings of the game's world to the user without resorting to datalogs?BattlesThe battle system for a FF game is a good one. Similar to FF XII you are only in control of one of your three party members at a time, with the computer taking over for the other two. You can assign "paradigms" to your party, with one of six being active at any one time, with the ability to switch to others mid-battle. This system works well throughout the entire storyline, but can occasionally cause problems when attempting optional late-game content. In some late-game scenarios it would be extremely helpful to have more control over the other two members of your party, and sometimes you might have to retry battles due to computer players making bad decisions. ExtrasAs stated earlier, there is a point late in the game in which you can explore/grind/take on side missions that really shines. This section of the game really feels more like a final fantasy game than the rest, and if you're a fan of the series then this section will definitely scratch your itch for more FF. If you're not a veteran, than this area still holds some value and interest if you're enjoying the RPG aspects of the game and want to go further. While some people might argue that it was frustrating to leave this section until the later parts of the game, I think it was actually a good idea. Players who only want to experience the story can do so and can completely ignore this section of the game. While others who want the ability to ignore the story for a bit and develop their characters and inventory further can do so without the worry of having missed certain items or content earlier in the game. With all the "missables" of previous FF games being a frustration to completionists (especially FFXII with the Zodiac Spear nonsense), leaving this content until later works out really well. There are plenty of challenging side-missions and achievements to hunt that will satisfy all but the most hardcore of FF fan.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Final Fantasy XIII is not a good Final Fantasy, but it's a really fun and gorgeous JRPG.The story follows two different worlds: Pulse and Cacoon, each so afraid of the others that even contact with someone from the other planet will cause friends and family to turn against each other in order to rid themselves of those affected. Ruled by benevloent creatures called fal'Cie, players follow a commando, Lightning, and the people she meets as they are touched and turned into l'Cie, or touched warriors, by a Pulse fal'Cie that had hidden on Cacoon for ages.The combat system features some FF staples such as Phoenix Downs, summons, and certain magics, but instead of picking abilities individually, most players will likely be auto-attacking. Instead, the challenge comes from its Role system, or Paradigms. Paradigms are customized for each party, and rather than selecting attacks, players will be juggling roles among their characters fairly heavily. The result is a little different from other FFs, but it's fast-paced, pretty fun, and can get fairly difficult if role combinations don't pit well against tougher fights. Characters can then be leveled up by putting points into their various roles.Perhaps the biggest criticism with the game comes from the exploration, as this is where XIII splits from previous titles. Instead of an open world environment, players are set along linear paths with little room to move about. There are no World Maps, airships to control, or forests filled with random battles to get lost in. It feels nothing like Final Fantasies in that that regard.However, franchise name aside, the maps tend to work. Most jRPGs are simply "Go From Point A to Point B" to begin with, even with World Maps. The tunnels make it easier to play in shorter bursts for people with busy lives, and they keep players from forgetting where to go if they put the game down for a few weeks. The game does open up significantly in Chapter 11, but for the most part the game trims the fat and focuses on the fights and getting through the story.It helps that the environments and character models are gorgeous. With the PC fixes/patches, everything is beautifully rendered with smooth models and bright color palette. The characters themselves are highly engaging (though some take longer to warm up to than others), and there's a great deal of cuteness scattered throughout. Even with the hallway maps, there is a great deal of content, and players can expect to spend 60+ hours easily to finish.I highly recommend this game if players can put the "Final Fantasy" name aside. There are certainly some great traditional FF elements here - big swords, Cid, a Moogleworks shop - but it doesn't feel like the classic games. That's perfectly ok. It's well worth the price when taken to be its own jRPG.

												เอาจริงๆ ผมไม่ค่อยเป็นขาประจำเกมแนว RPG สักเท่าไหร่ โดยเฉพาะ JRPG อย่างตระกูล Final Fantasy ผมเองก็ไม่เคยเล่นสักภาคเดียว พอได้มาลองเล่นตัวเถื่อนไปสักพักนึง...ก็นั่นแหละครับ ผมก็ไปควานหาเวอร์ชั่น Steam มาเก็บจนได้+ระบบของเกม ที่ไม่ซับซ้อน แต่ก็สามารถสร้างแนวการเล่นได้หลากหลาย และปรับได้ตามสถานการณ์ (มากกว่านั่งกดๆๆ ใส่สกิล บลาๆๆ)+ระบบอัพเกรดตัวละคร ที่เข้าใจง่ายมาก (ดีไซน์ออกมาสวยกว่าเกมอื่นอีก ฮ่าๆ) และถึงแม้ตัวละครหนึ่งตัวจะมีหลายอาชีพ แต่อัพเกรด stat ทั้งหลายจะแชร์กันได้+เพลงเพราะมากๆๆๆๆ+Character Design สวดยอดดดดดดดด (ตัวละครหญิง นี่ +ให้ล้าน)-ปรับกราฟิกได้ไม่เยอะมากนัก-เนื้อเรื่องช่วงแรกงง(และง่วง)มาก จับอะไรไม่ค่อยต่อกันได้ ตัดสลับไปๆ มาๆ ซะเยอะ (บางช่วงนี่ นั่งเล่นแค่ 1 นาที ดูคัตซีนไป 2-3 นาที) แต่พอผ่านสักพัก หลายอย่างเริ่มดีขึ้น เนื้อเรื่องเริ่มชัดเจนและปะติดปะต่อได้-Open World ไม่สุด ไม่ค่อยอิสระมาก-บอสบางตัว ยากมาก และเกมไม่ค่อยบอกใบ้ (เข้าใจว่าเกม JRPG เก่าๆ ก็ไม่มีบอกใบ้อยู่ละ ฮ่าๆ)สรุป ให้ 9/10 (ในฐานะที่ไม่เคยเล่น JRPG มาก่อนเลยในชีวิต มาเกมแรกก็ถือว่าสนุกดีครับ เพลินๆ ดี)

Posted: December 22, 2015
												As much as I wanted to like this game, the best I could do was tolerate it. Even with a modicum of interest in seeing the storyline unfold, it was hard going being dragged through one wearisome corridor of battles after another for the sake of just a moment or two of exposition; then another gruelling corridor. The new combat system doesn't involve you enough to keep it interesting. I appreciate what they were trying to achieve, but it's a system that leaves you feeling like a passenger, idly mashing the auto attack button, rather than a participent in the fight. It's not so bad a game as others would suggest, but it is difficult to recommend, even for a fan of the series.

It gets better later)All in all, i would rate this 10/10

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												This is, by far, the best Final Fantasy in the franchise; if not, it is certainly the most modern of them.Every time I sit down and play Final Fantasy XIII again, I find it to be even more thrilling than I remembered.  It's hard to get all the negative reviews and fanboy hatred for this title out of your head when you look at the game; until you play it.  Then the stunningly detailed visuals, the most coherent story in any FF game to date, and the deep many-layered characters pull you into an immersive world; two worlds, to be exact.  Alright, that's the short and sweet bit up top; that's the synopsis.  Below will be a page-long point-by-point rebuttal of the common view of this game; so that you folks who are trying to gauge if you want to spend your hard-earned money on this can get both sides of the story.So, to begin; all the criticism and hatred a lot of people have for this game is, in my mind, just them being nostsalgic and whining (fanboy syndrome).   What people hate about this game, I love.  What they say breaks the game, I say is the innovation that Square promised would revolutionize the JRPG genre.  Let's start this list!1) Linearity:  This is the number one complaint you hear about Final Fantasy XIII, "It is too linear."  Compared to what?  Fallout and Elder Scrolls?  It is, in my humble opinion, exactly as linear as any traditional JRPG usually is.  It's just waaaay more in-your-face about it.  The story AND the paths are one-directional.  Spoiler: You're on the run from folks.   The story is driven as though it were a tightly bound book.  Each page you turn is filled with exactly what you want and need to continue through that leg of the story; not with a bunch of ancillary baggage and side-quests that make the real story feel like some fading memory.2) Story:  This is the second complaint I tend to hear; people say that either the game is too story-driven, or that it didn't even attempt to have a coherent story.   This section will contain mild spoilers.  I will use broad generalizations, no names, just themes spoken of in broadstrokes:You start off in the middle of a holocaust (big props, Square); you're being sent to die for fear of contamination from an alien, hostile world.  You escape your bonds, you help stop the holocaust, odds are stacked against you, you run through hugely cinematic warzones, better than anything Square has ever done before.  Compelling from minute one.   The story then unfolds that there are two worlds, and they are at war with one another.  Your world (Cocoon), is made to seem like the haven of all humanity and the perfect paradise, but you learn it is darker than you thought.  There are these magical inter-dimensional type demi-gods (Cocoon Fal'Cie), they built your world, and they fight against the world below (Pulse) and its demi-gods (Pulse Fal'Cie).Compare this to my favorite Final Fantasy, FFVIII, and tell me that the story is less coherent.  FFVIII's story sports some child soldiers brainwashed in a floating terrorist/mercenary training facility in the sky!  They all grew up as kids in an orphanage, but not one of them remembers this because of mental heatlh damage resulting from military hardware they're required to use as...child soldiers.   You race through many nations and warzones to find that powerful Sorceresses control the face of world politics.  Then you find, in fact, it has always been one Sorceress, who can bend time and possess people.  Then she, in fact, kompresses all time-space into a kind of purpl'ish goo that you have to navigate through to reach the end-game.  Honestly, and I love FFVIII, but that story is ridiculous.  It would be hard-pressed to survive in novel form.  FFXIII, however, could easily make a novel.3) Voice Acting/Character Design:  People appear to hate Vanille, Snow, Hope, Lightning, and maybe Sazh and Fang too. Vanille is an upbeat young woman that sounds a bit 'slow' at first, yes, but I think they invented a fictitious accent (Pulsian) for her to use; which startles us Earthicans at first.  Snow is the archetypical hero; this isn't new.  Every Square game has a Snow.  Remember Zell?  Snow is way less annoying than Zell.  Imagine if Zell were voice-acted.  Now imagine Zell said the things Zell said in FFVIII, in a wheezy, energetic, high-pitched voice. I'd have let Zell die repeatedly.  Snow has a good voice-actor, it's just his lines are sometimes cheesy.  He's a self-proclaimed hero that's crushed by the guilt of his own failures.  Of course he's blustering.   Lightning, they claim, is one-dimensional.  People who say this didn't play the game, or don't understand the idea of character development.  She starts cold, she learns to trust.  The characters are well thought-out, look beautiful, and have remarkably well done, grade-A professional voice-acting.  For those that disagree, go back and play FFX and listen to Titus' grainy whining voice (that sounds like he's narrating from in a bathroom), then tell me FFXIII did a worse job.   People complain that Lightning is a trophy female protagonist with no personality.  She's essentially a better, female Squall, in my opinion.  They both can't trust, they both have deep pains from personal loss and people they failed to protect.  They're both strong and silent.  They both use gunblades; but Lightning's is ten times as awesome; exactly like Squall, but ten times as awesome.  That about sums her up.4) Music:  The best, period.  8 and 16-bit scores do not compare to this symphonic magnificence.  The music fits the setting, the mood, and it flows.  The battle theme is light years beyond anything Square has EVER done.  Thank god I don't need to listen to jarring synthesizer techno while I save the world anymore.  Square has always excelled at making original, moving soundtracks; this is by far their best.5) Visuals: Like a slice of an LSD-induced dream that was rendered into a game by Pixar.6) Terminology:  So, I've read reviews of people ragging on this game for all it's jargon, "What's a Gran Pulse? A Fal'what? Gestalt? Is that a german seasoning?"  There's like, seriously, ten words or something you will need to learn.   Gran Pulse and Cocoon are worlds, the only two worlds in the game, so it's not like they're a galactic compendium of planets you have to remember.  Fal'Cie are the demi-gods, a human bound by a Fal'Cie's magic to serve them is called a l'Cie, a human that fails to complete his focus given to him by the Fal'Cie becomes a C'ieth (like a zombie).  That's about it, really.  The rest is just come-and-go.  Gestalt is just a meter you fill when you beat up the summons you're trying to acquire.  It's really a trite complaint.  Every RPG has it's own jargon, let alone FF games.  GF's, materia, mako energies, Ivalice, Shinra, etc.  FF is renowned for it's own jargon.  Jargon, in this context, just means unique story concepts.  Unique story concepts generally mean more attention to detail, more depth of story, and more immersion in the end.7) The Battle System:  People either hate it or they love it.  I think it's, by far, the best battle system in any FF game other than XII.  The people that complain it's too simple are playing on easy mode.  I die routinely, and I am a twenty year veteran of RPG's.  Once you reach Pulse, there are regular mobs that are like mini-bosses, and there are daunting challenges all around you.  It's a new system, but not at all shallow. The infamous 'auto-battle' is a feature you can choose to never use with one menu option.All in all, the fanboys' critique seems to be irrational, raging nostalgia lashing out with venomous spite at a masterpiece that failed to reach their dreams' fondest hopes.  In other words, they got let down and took it out on Square.   This game is easily 9/10.  The port has no graphics options, beware.  It runs fine on my PC, though.  Square will patch the game in December to fix this.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I said I would repost after playing the game. I can't comment on the patches because my system (stats follow) handled the game beautifully. The only times I missed 1080p (versus the 720p fullscreen) on a decent 42' screen was when I missed antialiasing/anistropic filtering settings. Basically if you pay too much attention to other characters on the map, you may see edges that aren't exactly smooth.MY RATING: That said, I give this game 9/10, considering it's an FF jRPG classic and the graphics are amazing and the port is really good.DISMISSAL OF GRAPHICS WHINERS WITHOUT APPROPRIATE HARDWARE: As I said before, I'm a software developer, and, using my knowledge of code and now experience with the game, I don't think the character models, textures, etc. need any updating to 1080p. Instead, let folks add AA and such, if they can't already get that through their graphics driver. It would ruin the original graphics, imho! I heard someone complain that the computer got the lesser quality cutscenes, but 50GB is enough for a game, imho, and, again, this is the definitive modern jRPG non-MMO graphically and otherwise as far as I'm concerned.SUMMARY: So, that done, on to the summary of the game: be prepared to not understand the story or how combat works completely for 4-8 hours, depending on the speed you play jRPGs. But this game delivers in length- not quite as long as I'd wish in a perfect world, but, being completionist, it took me at least 120hrs to get through. You can handle that, as the crazy FF fan who can't choose between FF, FFIII, FFIV, and FFVI for the best FF, right? FFVII was great, no question, but not in the running... kind of like FFX.STORY: actually not bad, after you understand what le'cie are... the voice acting is very good, including the annoying teenage female character who later develops. The story draws various types of relationships between the characters, drawing you into the necessity of the quest. Altogether, it's somewhat contrived, but, hey, go retrieve four crystals and no further explanation!GAME MECHANICS: The most annoying thing is the lack of a world-map like most final fantasy series games... a lot of the fun/sense of accomplishment of other FFs is when you gain a vehicle that allows you to visit those "secret" places you couldn't go to before. So, I think this is where the "linear" criticism comes from. You will see a multi-level large world environment. And there is an elementary "side-quest" system, and you can still go through areas again and again (it sometimes gets old, but seldom, since the wonderful music and varied environments keep you in it) to chase after the ultimate badassdom.The class system/grouped-combat feels confining for about 4-8 hours until you realize the variety of skills each character specializes in and that the system makes "formation" of front/back seem like "Goodnight, Moon." Though I love that book. You can play the combat in so many ways- I recommend ignoring the timer-based results of combat... just try all sorts of techniques out... you can speed-kill later.COMBAT: There are people who hate the fact that a jRPG is not Truly turn-based, and vice-versa. I like both, especially that correct blend that gives me time to decide strategy and "units of time" to work with, while reasonably limiting the decision as to sometimes influence my decisions. Hence, the "auto-battle" technique you're familiar with so far. Guess what? "Auto-battle" is surprisingly often what you want to do - healing) auto-heal will pick the person who needs healz the most tank) well, depends how you like to tank, but it spams some sort of guard skill, which you'd usually do anyway. Taunting skills are used too much, but you can always stop the queue after you successfully taunt, giving the skill added value since it auto-picks non-taunted targets.The bosses are challenging to a mid-aged gamer who played each FF. Most teach you to use new game-mechanics, and there are definite tough-fights if you go seeking them. And the bosses are like "wait, whoa- look twice."Anyway, the combat system has true depth, give it some time, and once you have some good commands, you're only badass if you set the default command to "abilities" instead of "auto-battle."END: In the end, FFXIII really delivers what you'd expect of Square *coughSOFT* Enix. The port is pretty well done considering some annoying FF ports in the past, that felt half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FFXIII is ftw once you realize that it's a post-MMO jRPG that chose a lot of the good parts of an MMO without being online. But don't think it's dumbed-down, because it has worthy challenges. This is truly the definitive jRPG of the post-MMO world, with all the bells and whistles you'd expect, imho. Not that I don't log in to FFXIV now and again ;)

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												I had no technical problems with this game it runs fine.  The combat and mechanics are fine if a bit over top cartoony.I wanted to like this game and played all the way through but in the end I have to just describe it as bad.  The problem is, if you are going to have a linear story based game then the story needs to make sense and be interesting.  The plot in this game is literally the main characters wandering around never knowining what to do next.  After having no clue what is happening the whole time, the evil bosses then give cliched speeches telling the heroes what to do next.  It is truely awful.This isnt just bad translation or acting.  The characters actually endlessly discuss that they never know what to do next.  That is the plot.   Square literally has no idea how to write a plot and dialogue that makes any sense for them to follow.  This is really to bad because alot of other things about the game are great.  The characters themselves are fairly interesting and the English voice acting is actually top notch making me want to like the characters.  The actual plot and sequence of events is just eyerolling and unforgivable.If anyone is totally new to the Final Fantasy games, get Final Fantasy 10 in the bargain bin instead of this one.  It is better in just about every way imaginable with a story that actually makes some sense.  It is the difference between "This is our story..." and what story?

												Final Fantasy XIII: Visuals:-Great visuals-Really pretty-Clean and not many (if any) visual bugs-Great character visuals-Lightning is <3Audio-Pretty good audio-Good voice actingGameplay-Fun gameplay if you are into JRPG  type games-May seem  like you have freedom to roam but its very linear-Interesting skills/ combination gameplay-Storyline is interesting-Not for everybodyOverall:FFXIII is an interesting and fun game if you have an interest in these types of games. If it seems like something you would like Im sure you would enjoy, but otherwise I would probably stay away or at least watch some gameplay of it and see if its something worth buying6/10

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												This game is very beautiful. The graphics are amazing and the characters are good. They are have a reason to do what they are doing for the story and it's fantastic. The gameplay is fun. You only control one character during battles and there is an option to "Auto" battle but i never use that because what is the point of that. People say this game is boring because of that option, but if you don't use it the game is much better. Everyone complains about the linearity of the game and I knew about it but I didn't know exactly what they meant, so here is what they mean by linear. In most other FF games you can freely go to towns or villages that you have previously been to but this games is just forward all the time. There are no towns, no safe areas, no shops, or anything like that. Just the characters running pretty much down a hallway. The only "stops" are save points along the path that also serves as a shop. All in all, it's a decent game, if you don't mind the linearity of it then i think you will love this game just as i do.

												This is, by far, the best Final Fantasy in the franchise; if not, it is certainly the most modern of them.Every time I sit down and play Final Fantasy XIII again, I find it to be even more thrilling than I remembered.  It's hard to get all the negative reviews and fanboy hatred for this title out of your head when you look at the game; until you play it.  Then the stunningly detailed visuals, the most coherent story in any FF game to date, and the deep many-layered characters pull you into an immersive world; two worlds, to be exact.  Alright, that's the short and sweet bit up top; that's the synopsis. What people hate about this game, I love.  What they say breaks the game, I say is the innovation that Square promised would revolutionize the JRPG genre.  Let's start this list!1) Linearity:  This is the number one complaint you hear about Final Fantasy XIII, "It is too linear."  Compared to what?  Fallout and Elder Scrolls? Spoiler: You're on the run from folks.   The story is driven as though it were a tightly bound book. This section will contain mild spoilers.  I will use broad generalizations, no names, just themes spoken of in broadstrokes:You start off in the middle of a holocaust (big props, Square); you're being sent to die for fear of contamination from an alien, hostile world.  You escape your bonds, you help stop the holocaust, odds are stacked against you, you run through hugely cinematic warzones, better than anything Square has ever done before.  Compelling from minute one.   The story then unfolds that there are two worlds, and they are at war with one another.  Your world (Cocoon), is made to seem like the haven of all humanity and the perfect paradise, but you learn it is darker than you thought.  There are these magical inter-dimensional type demi-gods (Cocoon Fal'Cie), they built your world, and they fight against the world below (Pulse) and its demi-gods (Pulse Fal'Cie).Compare this to my favorite Final Fantasy, FFVIII, and tell me that the story is less coherent.  FFVIII's story sports some child soldiers brainwashed in a floating terrorist/mercenary training facility in the sky!  They all grew up as kids in an orphanage, but not one of them remembers this because of mental heatlh damage resulting from military hardware they're required to use as...child soldiers.   You race through many nations and warzones to find that powerful Sorceresses control the face of world politics.  Then you find, in fact, it has always been one Sorceress, who can bend time and possess people.  Then she, in fact, kompresses all time-space into a kind of purpl'ish goo that you have to navigate through to reach the end-game.  Honestly, and I love FFVIII, but that story is ridiculous.  It would be hard-pressed to survive in novel form.  FFXIII, however, could easily make a novel.3) Voice Acting/Character Design:  People appear to hate Vanille, Snow, Hope, Lightning, and maybe Sazh and Fang too. Vanille is an upbeat young woman that sounds a bit 'slow' at first, yes, but I think they invented a fictitious accent (Pulsian) for her to use; which startles us Earthicans at first.  Snow is the archetypical hero; this isn't new.  Every Square game has a Snow.  Remember Zell?  Snow is way less annoying than Zell.  Imagine if Zell were voice-acted.  Now imagine Zell said the things Zell said in FFVIII, in a wheezy, energetic, high-pitched voice. I'd have let Zell die repeatedly.  Snow has a good voice-actor, it's just his lines are sometimes cheesy.  He's a self-proclaimed hero that's crushed by the guilt of his own failures.  Of course he's blustering.   Lightning, they claim, is one-dimensional.  People who say this didn't play the game, or don't understand the idea of character development.  She starts cold, she learns to trust.  The characters are well thought-out, look beautiful, and have remarkably well done, grade-A professional voice-acting.  For those that disagree, go back and play FFX and listen to Titus' grainy whining voice (that sounds like he's narrating from in a bathroom), then tell me FFXIII did a worse job.   People complain that Lightning is a trophy female protagonist with no personality.  She's essentially a better, female Squall, in my opinion.  They both can't trust, they both have deep pains from personal loss and people they failed to protect.  They're both strong and silent.  They both use gunblades; but Lightning's is ten times as awesome; exactly like Squall, but ten times as awesome.  That about sums her up.4) Music:  The best, period.  8 and 16-bit scores do not compare to this symphonic magnificence.  The music fits the setting, the mood, and it flows.  The battle theme is light years beyond anything Square has EVER done.  Thank god I don't need to listen to jarring synthesizer techno while I save the world anymore.  Square has always excelled at making original, moving soundtracks; this is by far their best.5) Visuals: Like a slice of an LSD-induced dream that was rendered into a game by Pixar.6) Terminology:  So, I've read reviews of people ragging on this game for all it's jargon, "What's a Gran Pulse? Square will patch the game in December to fix this.

I like both, especially that correct blend that gives me time to decide strategy and "units of time" to work with, while reasonably limiting the decision as to sometimes influence my decisions. Hence, the "auto-battle" technique you're familiar with so far. Guess what? "Auto-battle" is surprisingly often what you want to do - healing) auto-heal will pick the person who needs healz the most tank) well, depends how you like to tank, but it spams some sort of guard skill, which you'd usually do anyway. Taunting skills are used too much, but you can always stop the queue after you successfully taunt, giving the skill added value since it auto-picks non-taunted targets.The bosses are challenging to a mid-aged gamer who played each FF. Most teach you to use new game-mechanics, and there are definite tough-fights if you go seeking them. And the bosses are like "wait, whoa- look twice."Anyway, the combat system has true depth, give it some time, and once you have some good commands, you're only badass if you set the default command to "abilities" instead of "auto-battle."END: In the end, FFXIII really delivers what you'd expect of Square *coughSOFT* Enix. The port is pretty well done considering some annoying FF ports in the past, that felt half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FFXIII is ftw once you realize that it's a post-MMO jRPG that chose a lot of the good parts of an MMO without being online. But don't think it's dumbed-down, because it has worthy challenges. This is truly the definitive jRPG of the post-MMO world, with all the bells and whistles you'd expect, imho. Not that I don't log in to FFXIV now and again ;)

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Having finished the game before on PS3, I feel qualified to say that, for all intents and purposes, this is a pretty decent port of the game that all Final Fantasy fans should try. I'm not going to give my opinion of the game in detail but I will say that it is very underrated and, if nothing else, worth experiencing at this price for the visuals and audio alone. Square Enix is truly in a class of their own when it comes to audio/visual design and FFXIII is one of the best places to see it until XV is released. This new port of the game is optimized to run at 60 frames per second, maximum, though you might have a hard time hitting that consistently if your system isn't configured properly. By enabling Vsync through my GPU drivers for this game, forcing Anisotropic Filtering (which is unrelated but really helps the visuals), and setting my PC to Maximum Performance in the power settings I was able to get 60fps at almost all times during battle and field scenes, though cutscenes (especially the pre-rendered ones of course) tended to hover around 30fps, which is fine.In general, if you were ever interested in this game and are very easily swayed by gorgeous, artistic visuals and sound, you will enjoy this game, especially at a discount like this. The Japanese dual audio option also helps if you find the English voices grating on your ears, which is subjective; I'm fine with them but options are always nice! It's true that, at the moment, the game is locked at 720p and you use the ESC key to quit the game, but those are not nearly as big of a deal as they're made out to be as long as your GPU or monitor properly scales the game to your screen size. The game uses a lot of post-processing effects so that the 720p visuals are barely noticeable on my 1080p screen except for occasional aliasing, and the game runs so smoothly with those small tweaks that I barely notice anything "wrong" with how the game looks anyway. In the end, if you've intended to give this game a try or even experience it again, there is no better time than now.My general, relevant specs, if anyone is curious, are:CPU: Intel i5 3570k OC'd from 3.8 to 4.2ghzGPU: Nvidia GTX 770Monitor: Asus 1080p 60hz

content:
Posted: January 28
												Fun JRPG with engaging plot, great visuals and good soundtrack held back by a few flaws. I would recommend this to anyone that is a fan of the series and it is a great starting point for everyone else.The drawbacks of this game is the lackluster performance, level design and combat. For the most part performance is steady however all that changes when you get to Gran Pulse near the end of the game where enemies start popping in and out while your framerate almost halves (and this on a GTX 1060 at 1080p). The level design is very basic. The majority of the game you just run in a straight line, going from one cutscene to the next. It is very linear.The combat takes a long time to get engaging. After say 20 hours in, when your characters develop enough to get attacks and varied team combinations, it will lead to some nice battles here in there. For the most part there are few challenging enemies in the game. For the most part you will spam the autobattle button.That being said the characters are memorable and the story will keep you engaged. There is a lot of cutscenes in this game and they are, for the most part, well done. The humor is hit and miss. One of the best thing this game has going for it, aside from the graphics and well done animations, is the music. It really does stand out and I found it great.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Product received for free
												The game isn't as bad as everyone made it out to be. Was the story pretty linear? I suppose so, but if you compare it to the other FF games, they were pretty linear themselves. I think they presented FF13 well enough to make it into the FF series though I didn't really feel an ounce of emotion while playing the game. Sure there were some cliche scenes and dialogue that makes you want to tear your eyes out, but what's an FF game without some cliche scenes and cheezy lines? The story itself wasn't good or bad. It was pretty much your average save the world story and the ONLY thing I was looking forward to was Serah and Snow getting married. When I finished the game, I was like WHERE WAS THE WEDDING? It was half the reason why I finished the game. The other half was to see whether Fang and Vanille were either in a family-sister relationship or a romantic relationship with each other. I had a feeling that Square Enix was sort of in the middle between the two types of relationships since after all they are a world known company and game developer.The battle system in my opinion was actually a nice change of pace compared to some of the older FF games. The old turn based battle is okay and all since it gives you all the time in the world to make a strategy or eat a snack! The introduction of the paradigm system made the game refreshing and new, though IMHO it isn't exactly hard to learn or master. You just need to know the weaknesses of your enemies and adapt your paradigm decks to them. Honestly, the only BIG flaw I cared about in this game was the travelling system, especially if you hadn't completed any missions yet. It's such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to move through Gran Pulse when you have no way to teleport or travel once you hit chapter 11 in the game. Even post-game, it's still a hassle to move around and that sort of turned me off from actually completing all the achievements in the game.It took me around 38 hours to beat the game itself. I don't regret wasting 38 hours exploring the breathtaking scenery they created in this game or listening to the beautiful music they implemented for each area. For example, the bgm in Oerba - the home of Fang and Vanille. In my opinion, Oerba had the best bgm out of all the areas because it really made you understand the feeling of losing a home and never able to return to it. The ending song, no not "My Hands" by Leona Lewis (totally ruined the English version of the game), but "Kimi Ga Iru Kara" (Because You Are Here) by Sayuri Sugawara made me feel satisfied with the game. Are you hesitant to play this game? Just buy it and try it out yourself. You won't regret spending $15 - even though this was gifted to me.

content:
Posted: March 26
												Game that has been released halfway through development. Would recommend only to die-hard Final Fantasy fans but they already have played this game.The battle system has a lot of potential and can keep interest up for the game. Unfortunately the game suffers from unsufficient testing and being published too soon. There are many points in time that that you end up wondering "what on earth were the developers thinking when they did this?" If this had not been a Final Fantasy game I would have stopped playing much earlier but I thought that when the problems surfaced were just lone hiccups.Quite often you find yourself losing a fight with no idea what you did wrong. This happens even if you have your party leveled up as much as they can be at those points. You simply have to google what to do. Even then you might be left wondering why the solution you googled worked.The final straw for me was the final boss. The fight was going completely fine and was taking way quite some time as the final battles tend to do until I suddenly just lost and I didn't understand why. I had to google the last attact the boss had used (one it had used couple of times during the fight). The thing is the final boss has an attack that has a 50% chance to kill a party member. If you party leader dies, you lose the fight. Having 3 party members this means every time the boss uses that attact you have a 15% chance of losing the fight.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I said I would repost after playing the game. I can't comment on the patches because my system (stats follow) handled the game beautifully. The only times I missed 1080p (versus the 720p fullscreen) on a decent 42' screen was when I missed antialiasing/anistropic filtering settings. Basically if you pay too much attention to other characters on the map, you may see edges that aren't exactly smooth.MY RATING: That said, I give this game 9/10, considering it's an FF jRPG classic and the graphics are amazing and the port is really good.DISMISSAL OF GRAPHICS WHINERS WITHOUT APPROPRIATE HARDWARE: As I said before, I'm a software developer, and, using my knowledge of code and now experience with the game, I don't think the character models, textures, etc. need any updating to 1080p. Instead, let folks add AA and such, if they can't already get that through their graphics driver. It would ruin the original graphics, imho! I heard someone complain that the computer got the lesser quality cutscenes, but 50GB is enough for a game, imho, and, again, this is the definitive modern jRPG non-MMO graphically and otherwise as far as I'm concerned.SUMMARY: So, that done, on to the summary of the game: be prepared to not understand the story or how combat works completely for 4-8 hours, depending on the speed you play jRPGs. But this game delivers in length- not quite as long as I'd wish in a perfect world, but, being completionist, it took me at least 120hrs to get through. You can handle that, as the crazy FF fan who can't choose between FF, FFIII, FFIV, and FFVI for the best FF, right? FFVII was great, no question, but not in the running... kind of like FFX.STORY: actually not bad, after you understand what le'cie are... the voice acting is very good, including the annoying teenage female character who later develops. The story draws various types of relationships between the characters, drawing you into the necessity of the quest. Altogether, it's somewhat contrived, but, hey, go retrieve four crystals and no further explanation!GAME MECHANICS: The most annoying thing is the lack of a world-map like most final fantasy series games... a lot of the fun/sense of accomplishment of other FFs is when you gain a vehicle that allows you to visit those "secret" places you couldn't go to before. So, I think this is where the "linear" criticism comes from. You will see a multi-level large world environment. And there is an elementary "side-quest" system, and you can still go through areas again and again (it sometimes gets old, but seldom, since the wonderful music and varied environments keep you in it) to chase after the ultimate badassdom.The class system/grouped-combat feels confining for about 4-8 hours until you realize the variety of skills each character specializes in and that the system makes "formation" of front/back seem like "Goodnight, Moon." Though I love that book. You can play the combat in so many ways- I recommend ignoring the timer-based results of combat... just try all sorts of techniques out... you can speed-kill later.COMBAT: There are people who hate the fact that a jRPG is not Truly turn-based, and vice-versa. I like both, especially that correct blend that gives me time to decide strategy and "units of time" to work with, while reasonably limiting the decision as to sometimes influence my decisions. Hence, the "auto-battle" technique you're familiar with so far. Guess what? "Auto-battle" is surprisingly often what you want to do - healing) auto-heal will pick the person who needs healz the most tank) well, depends how you like to tank, but it spams some sort of guard skill, which you'd usually do anyway. Taunting skills are used too much, but you can always stop the queue after you successfully taunt, giving the skill added value since it auto-picks non-taunted targets.The bosses are challenging to a mid-aged gamer who played each FF. Most teach you to use new game-mechanics, and there are definite tough-fights if you go seeking them. And the bosses are like "wait, whoa- look twice."Anyway, the combat system has true depth, give it some time, and once you have some good commands, you're only badass if you set the default command to "abilities" instead of "auto-battle."END: In the end, FFXIII really delivers what you'd expect of Square *coughSOFT* Enix. The port is pretty well done considering some annoying FF ports in the past, that felt half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FFXIII is ftw once you realize that it's a post-MMO jRPG that chose a lot of the good parts of an MMO without being online. But don't think it's dumbed-down, because it has worthy challenges. This is truly the definitive jRPG of the post-MMO world, with all the bells and whistles you'd expect, imho. Not that I don't log in to FFXIV now and again ;)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Please bear in mind that I've played over 100+ hours in the 360 version of this game which is the reason for my low playtime.While many people may not like it, this game is deserving of the Final Fantasy name. Why? Because it FEELS like a Final Fantasy; there's great character development, pacing, storyline, battles and of course outstanding music.This is a perfect starting point for those new to the franchise. Although it may be confusing and overwhelming at first, I strongly suggest for those who are confused by the opening (which I will admit explains nothing) is to check the datalog entries on L'cie and Fal'cie etc.Now. Onto the meat of the game.Like previous FFs, progress is largely done by exploration and battles. Sadly, exploration is where the game falls short. No doubt you've heard of the lineraty of the game, and its true. You will be walking in a hallway-like fashion most of the time. However, the game does open up at a late stage in the game which is great for those yearning for side-quests and exploration - that they are plenty.Instead of following the traditional method of Turn-Based battles, all battles will be in real time which makes the game far more interesting and difficult at parts.On the whole, this was my first FF and I loved it. Where it falls short is on-the-rails exploration and the game holding your hand most of the time. However, this will be undoubtedly be overpowered by the sheer production values and experience this game possess.

number of helpful: 17 of 34 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Final Fantasy XIII is, as the name implies, the 13th main-line Final fantasy title. And much like previous titles, the game has very little to do with the rest of the series, apart from some minor reoccurring elements, like the Chocobos (a kind of large bird that some people ride on). Let's get the most glaring issue with this game out of the way. The port is terrible. Slowdown for no obvious reason was quite common, but what was worse is that the game has really bad keyboard controls, yet there's a common bug that causes the save menu to freeze if you have an Xinput controller plugged in, and it does not play nice with a DirectInput controller. It recognizes DirectInput controllers, just not all buttons on it.Graphics & soundFinal Fantasy XIII is a really nice looking game. It keeps a mostly consistent art style, with interesting looking  enemies and beautiful environments. Animations leave a bit to desire, but they're not terrible.The soundtrack is a disappointment. The Final Fantasy series is known for its great music, but here it just felt flat and uninteresting. Thinking back on the game, I don't actually remember any of the songs, yet I remember songs from the FF games I played in the 90's. Voice acting is mostly good, but not outstanding. The voice actors do a good job with the material they're given, even if there's no standout performances, but it feels like they are hampered more by the script than with any lack of talent.Story & writingThe story always plays an important role in the Final Fantasy series, and 13 is no exception. There are a lot of cutscenes and a lot of dialogue.The game takes place in a place called Cocoon, which is led by a fal'Cie. There's the l'Cie from pulse that are the enemy to Cocoon, and if you have no idea what a fal'Cie or a l'Cie is, then you've just experienced one of the major issues with the writing in this game. It loves to throw in-universe terms at you without explaining them. After a while you will figure out what a fal'Cie or a l'Cie is, but it's something that the writers seem to have expected you to know getting into the game.The fal'Cie are supernatural beings of great power, who more or less rule the world. The l'Cie are humans branded by the fal'Cie, who need to fulfill a task given to them, or else they'll be transformed into monsters. The branding also gives them special powers.The game throws you right into the story, some people who were near a pulse fal'Cie (the enemy of the l'Cie of Cocoon, where the main characters  are from) getting deported, due to fear of them being marked and dangerous. The main characters want to stop the deportation, which is protected by the soldiers of Cocoon. And it's boring. You're not really given any motivation for why you should care about anyone at this point, and the game does a terrible job at actually explaining what's going on, who the people are, it just expects you to be engaged in the story already. The characters are also introduced as 1 dimensional stereotypes with little in the way of personality outside of their one dominant trait. This goes on for nearly 3 hours.Then the characters reach the Pulse Fal'Cie and get branded, and this is where the game actually gets started. Now you're given some motivation, and the characters start showing some emotion (though it still takes a while before they really evolve into something relatable9. In terms of story pacing, this is terrible, you should not have to sit through nearly 3 hours of made up words that the game just refuses to explain and drip fed story before it gets anywhere, at least not in a game that tries to put the story in focus. Once the story really gets going, it actually turns into something that's relatively good, and moves along at a mostly good pace, up until the last 3rd of the game, where it starts to feel drawn out and padded once more. Overall, in the hands of better writers and with a better pacing, this story could have been quite good.GameplayFinal Fantasy XIII uses a real time combat system, unlike most previous games in the series. You only control one character, who you can give direct orders to. The rest of the characters are just given "stances", and they'll do whatever they want to do that fits into this stance. It works, but much like the story taking 3h to get started, so does the gameplay. Until you've become l'Cie all you can do is attack and use items, and there's really no skill or decision-making involved. You just attack. You won't get experience until you've become a l'Cie either.Once you've become l'Cie, you can start earning levels, and leveling up is handled in a less direct way than most Final Fantasy titles. You have skill paths for each stance, and you invest points into them to get stronger. Some give new abilities (but just for that stance), while other improve your stats. It's not a very complex system, all you really do is move along mostly linear progression paths, but you at least get to chose which path you want to invest your skillpoints in at any given them.Level navigation is more or less entirely linear. You move through long corridors with enemies. No chance to deviate from the path, other than possibly take 2 steps to one side to open a chest at certain points. Most FF games are linear, but none are as linear as this one. This makes for rather monotonous gameplay.Most enemies are easy enough to take down, and you don't really need to worry about stances and such all that much. Bosses though, those are at the same time almost always really easy and really frustrating to face. The game developers figured that by just giving the bosses huge health pools, they would make them harder,. Most bosses during the second half of the game are just damage sponges with some special attacks you need to watch out for. My advice is to just play the game on easy, they have smaller health pools if you do (an advice I wish had been given to me before I started playing, as I played through the entire thing on normal, apart from the last 3 bosses).Final thoughtsFinal Fantasy XIII is a deeply flawed game. The main story is actually rather interesting, but it's ruined by poor writing and pacing. The port is really bad, and you might have to play through the game with really awkward keyboard controls. The gameplay is also a bit monotonous, but were it not for the damage sponge bosses, it would have been alright at least. Overall, this is a game that can, and probably should, be skipped. You won't have a terrible time playing it, after the first 3 hours at least (which were the most boring 3 first hours I've ever seen in a JRPG), but there are so many better games out there that deserve your time and money instead. Games like Tales of Zestiria or most previous Final Fantasy titles.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Just a warning to anyone looking to buy this game. TLDR - Horrible porting job.There are no graphical settings. You are locked in to 720p and have no control over texture quality, antialiasing  or anything else. You can use GeDoSaTo to get around this, which will allow you to get the resolution up, but it has no effect on the pre-rendered cut scenes (of which there are plenty).The game couldn't tell the difference between a 360 controller and a joystick, wouldn't let me choose, and refused to accept the latter's input until the former had been unplugged.It's a good thing that the save points are so close together, because pressing escape will immediately  exit the game. No warnings. Straight to desktop. Why did they bind the ragequit button to one that is normally used to exit a menu?!?Don't expect to alt-tab either. And attempt to minimise the game will make it crash. If you're unlucky enough to have something minimise the game (add new hardware wizard, I'm looking at you!) you're going to be re-loading your save from the most recent point.If the one-man team behind 'From Dust' can do an awesome PC Port, I don't see why Square Enix can't. Not worth the money in it's current state.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Linear, on-rails, inept at storytelling. Combat system an absolute borefest for the first two hours, it gets better afterwards, but it won't let you choose your leader and, in six hours of gameplay, it wouldn't let me pick my battle team either. I played up to a particularly annoying enemy called Odin and lost my patience after the first five tactics didn't work, because the guy would get my only other team member killed.I would've stomached trying a bit more, but what for? Nonsensical dialogue and plot points that never get explained, all centered around the most irritating character since Squall? On top of that, while the Paradigm system is interesting on its own, battles ended up being a "screw around with the menus" excercise. I have Microsoft Excel for that.Your mileage may vary.Incidentally, Japanese audio is left in, which is a huge plus and I have to congratulate Square Enix for it, but the port drops at 30fps at random, no matter how high or low the settings, for no good reason. Didn't try keyboard controls, but the gamepad's fine and responsive. The PC port isn't too bad, but the game is just not good enough to justify the price. I got it on a sale and I have buyer's remorse.

												This is my first time playing through Final Fantasy XIII and 8 hours in I'm satisfied so far. The combat system is new, the roles have names I'm not used to, but you adjust quickly and figure it out as you go. I was expecting to play the night I purchased it but wasn't finished with the download until noon the following morning.In terms of bugs and glitches, I'm assuming the November update made some big changes because I am having 0 issues with the game so far. I will update my review if something comes up but having played for a few days I am content with the quality of this port. I'll definitely be buying a copy of XIII-2.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												What's the big deal?  The game itself is enjoyable.  As far as it being a horrible port?  Relax!!  Yeah, it's obvious they left out most settings and customization that pc gamers demand, but is it a deal breaker?  Seriously, for the price?  I've paid much more for a pc game that is horribly flawed and crashes to desktop every time I sneeze. So after a lengthy download, the game booted up flawlessly, menus and animations all seem to work fine.  The graphics and visuals are good, even at a lower res that i'm accustomed to.  Characters look better than alot of the landscape textures, but hey it's not a brand new game.  Music and atmospheric sounds are very good.  Some of the sound effects could be better (character footsteps), but overall sound is very good.  I've put a couple hours in with no glitches or crashes, and look forward to continuing to see what this game has to offer.  If you plan on purchasing, just wait for a sale.  As far as all the negativity goes, to each there own.  Some peoples horses are higher than others.
