content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Where do i begin with Final Fantasy XIII?This game gives a very love hate relationship. I'll try my best to split the good and bad because i find it easier to point out the bad rather than what i actually like/love about this game. (SPOILERS AHEAD)Good:-Square Enix hardley ever dissapoint when it comes to delievering a lore and setting for a Final Fantasy title. The whole L'cie concept and how it can result is to me, original. The design of Cocoon and Gran Pulse feel very natural with the story arch alongside the whole Fal'cie and L'cie idea.-Music. Now this i can say whole heartedly that Square Enix NEVER dissapoint when it comes to scoring a Final Fantasy game. If i were to give you a taste of why i think it's amazing then listen to this song. 


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy 13 OST - Disc Four - 22 - Ending Credits 

			Views: 75,558		

			FULL PLAYLIST HERE http://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=7C498688F14F6A0D The complete and original 4-Disc soundtrack for Final Fantasy XIII, the hit role-playing video game developed and published...		

The music in every big Final Fantasy title always make the lore feel very alive and rich, this part of the series that we all know and love is fortunately carried through in this title and i'm sure you'll all enjoy it.-Game length. While i have 102 hours on my record i truly completed the game in 83 hours and the rest is where i left the game on and fell asleep but Final Fantasy only tracks time i've been actually playing. Final Fantasy is never usually a short game, especially because these titles are in development for many, many years. Don't worry about not thinking you might not get your money's worth out of this game because trust me, you will and there's still another 2 titles ahead of this that you have to play still. -For the overall goodside i'm still not sure on what makes me love this game even with all of it's flaws (which i state below). I think the character i love the most is Sazh, he's the one who seems like he's the only one who's slightly true to the objective of the game. Getting Dajh back as a father figure is his biggest drive, even though he doesn't seem very driven throughout most of the game because he proclaims himself as "old" and "tired/fed up". Like i said, this game gives a very love/hate relationship between itself and the player.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Bad:-Snow Villiers.-A lot of the characters just moan throughout the game and a lot of the lines are pretty tacky/cheesy/cliche. Snow Villiers is the biggest example. Not only is he a cocky character but the majority of his lines are super far fetched about being a "hero" and if it's not that then he's always screaming and crying about Serah and holding that damn crystal tear. I also find Hope to be very annoying throughout the first half of the game, yes he lost his mother but he bottles his emotions towards Snow and starts to give of the vibe of an annoying little emo kid that only has character development because of a dead mother.-The last boss, Orphan. Not only do you fight barthandelus for the third time in the game but you then go on to fight Orphan straight after without any preperation and by then you might have used all of your TP to even have any left against Orphan. My biggest complaint about Orphan is the attack it uses and it's name ends in "Wrath". I can't express how ******* ANGRY that move makes me. That move has a chance, yes, A CHANCE, of instant killing either you, your party members or nobody at all. I want to put my keyboard through my ******* monitor when i'm close to killing Orphan and i get instantly killed by ******* CHANCE! To put the very final boss fight to rest in review, After you defeat the annoying Orphan you go on to fight Orphan's "final form" which is literally the easiest boss fight ever. Spam buffs and debuffs and Orphan II goes down in like 1-3 staggers. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall:I do recommend this game a lot as it is one of my favorite Final Fantasy titles and because in the ending i felt nothing but relief and i cried tears of joy, but i do warn you of the bad things about this game, seriously.

content:
Posted: January 15
												I like the cinematics and character development but the story is a fluffy cringefest, as with most FF's in general but this..just lacks substance. The battle mechanics is horridly lackluster but the one thing I like is the Crystarium system. I yawned many times during the game and found it to be an effective sleeping pill. Half of the hours I put in the game are afk hours to be honest. I bought this in a whim due to nostalgia..and also it was on sale. I recommend if you 1. Like being on auto pilot and linear storyline. 2. Want to torture yourself 3. Just want to complete the trophies in the Steam version (Me)I don't recommend this for long time FF fans because just..no unless you have nothing else to play. I revisited IX on console lately as it's great. Will try the Steam version when I feel like it in the future :) On the flipside the game helps my insomnia in several occasions. So I will put Yes for anyone who has problems getting some peaceful sleep because XIII WILL send you on an express train to Dream Land.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Rating: 8/10Final Fantasy 13 introduces a new type of combat that is both turn base and realtime strategy. Though slow at first, the game gradually picks up in gameplay. The progression system is very similar to FFX sphere system, but instead you spend Points to make your characters stronger. The story has an amazing plot however, can be very overwhelming and confusing at first. Thus requires much focus on dialogue and lore. However to the general census, many people do not seem to enjoy the game as much as I do.Overall I think the game is great and would recommend it to any Final Fantasy fan who wants something different. If you are unsure, you should definitely look up some gameplay footage and other reviews.

												I'm about 8hrs in the game is meh. Completley linear, terrible characters, gorgeous visuals, plot that is all over the place. I was captivated by the game at first as the combat system was likable and the graphics were stunning. Hours in you begin to realize that the gameplay has nothing to do with the story. Your characters don't grow and develop, you make no choices and are not involved in the plot, you just do flavorless battles and as a reward get to watch an anime.I think if you converted FF13 into a straight up CG movie, nothing would be lost. You are not the story.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This was the first Final Fantasy game that I played and while it had its moments I cannot recommend this game.  My main two issues were the mouse/keyboard controls and the repetitive nature of the second half of the game.Controls:  Probably the laziest effort put forwards on a console port that I've experienced.  Limited ability to rebind the keys, poor mouse utilization, and terrible camera functionality.  I did eventually get used to them, but there could have been so much improvement in the interface displays when using a mouse.  Essentially the mouse is turned into two buttons and there's no cursor.Repetition:  A personal issue but I don't want to have to grind in a single player RPG.  All of the enemies are simply reskins of the same few dozen models.  I ended up limping my way through the end of the game with 5 minute after 5 minute fights since I didn't feel like going out of my way to fight fodder enemies for fractional amounts of EXP.  Boss fights are obnoxiously long and several will take longer than 10 minutes of hitting a button twice every ~5 seconds.  Enemy levels/difficulty are a mystery leading to one shot deaths.  It took me around 35 hours to finish the game.  After the first 15 hours or so I just wanted it to be over.  The last few chapters are quite long.  If you're a fan of excruciating repetition, there are plenty of 'achievements' and completionist objectives.  But I'm glad that it's over and I can free up the 51gb for a new game.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Being a newbie at JRPG's I had a steep learning curve, but quickly found myself wondering how the clock got so late. I made the mistake of first playing FF XIII-2 and was extremely confused. If you have not played XIII yet, I highly suggest playing the first one before moving on to the second. I normally prefer being more involved in my RPGs, but this is a completely different genre with its own appeal. After completing the second chapter the game gets more involved. Think of the first few chapters as training. FF XIII is the first FInal Fantasy I have played (other than the MMO) and I think it is here to stay!

												I do not understand why people like this game.I put 300+ hours in FF12 on the PS2 a long time ago, so I figured I'd finaly give it's succesor a chance. But first of all, this game is, or at least the beginning of it, incredibly linear. Now that wouldn't be a bad thing if the dialogue was any good, but no, it is not. Seriously, the dialogue is just filled with stupendous clichés. The story might be oke, I did not play enough to form a reliable judgment about it.And then there's the combat. I hoped for something along the lines of FF12 where (in my remembrance at least) the combat involved some degree of tact in order to succeed. But in this game all I had to do was mash the auto combat button, and couldn't even do that for my allies, they were completely controlled by the AI.All in all, this was a rather dissapointing experience.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												The game runs really well on PC, even though sometimes the sync between the voice actors and sound gets knocked off but that's just my PC being dumb on occassion, very rarely does it occur otherwise. I enjoyed the story on PS3, and was happy to replay it, but if you are looking for something that is nonlinear, you are looking in the wrong place. For about the first 10-11 chapters (there are 13), you are constricted to hallways that determine your path, with the occasional offshoot (which deadend and force you to go back). In that sense it lacks the feel of some final fantasy games like FFVII or VIII. However, the character development and world building are very interesting, which is honestly the reason I keep going in the first place at this point. The normal mode is certainly brutal to those who cannot adapt to the ATB Gauge type of battle, where some battles seem impossible, which is why strategizing is key once you can switch people in your party. Like most people have said, the game is heavily tutorial-based, where 5-7 chapters are strictly teaching you how to play with the system and how to strategize with the mechanics. If you cannot deal with the mechanics or just want the story, there is an easy mode, which makes the battles easier to endure and grinding quicker than in normal mode. Also, once you get to a certain point, the open areas are really beautiful and give missions for you to do so that you can get better gear or more CP to level up. Overall, I feel it is a good game, though it lacks in some aspects.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												It is hard to recommand this game since i gave up on getting through it for now.I got 15 hours in and lost interest because of the very locked groups.15 hours in and I am still not allowed to choose which group of characters I want to use, neither am I allowed to use a full team, and from what I gather it will take another 5 hours before I am actually allowed to play the game.So at this point I am just giving up.However it was 15 hours of ok fun, so for the price it is I would still recommend it, and who knows maybe I will finish it another time.So now for how the game is:Combat is quite well functioning, you control 1 character and the other characters are auto controlled, although you control which roles they should be in, you do this from preset roles you set before combat. It is actually a good fun system which allows you to feel a lot of nice action while not having too much stress.The camera however is a plague, it jumps all over the place, is too far zoomed in so you sometime miss important skill clues getting you killed because of it, and you got little control over how your other characters use their skillset in the class, so they don’t always makes the smartest moves.The game is very linear, for the 15 hours I played I have done nothing but moving in one straight line without any ability to deviate from it.The story is quite good, but it seems to be Very short for what it is, without all the “wasted time” I think the story could be summarized until now in less then 15 min. even so it is enjoyable, and it is Very awesomely voice acted.I was quite impressed with the dialog, due to the names “snow, lightning, fang, hope, etc” I was expecting quite childish dialog but they were actually quite good and I found most dialog to be positive experiences ^^The progression system is sadly leaving much to be desired; there isn’t much progression choice to speak of, again everything is linear and because the cap on each role is so low you max them all out so easily, that there is no choice to be made.This is far from what we are used too in most ff games, but even so it does not take too much enjoyment away from the game.So well, this is my experience with the first 15 hours of the game.I would recommend it for the story and general feel; however, you need to know how linear everything is.

												It's my favorite FF game. The story is definitely confusing the first time you play; they could have done a much better job of explaining the worldstate throughout the intro. content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This was the first Final Fantasy game that I played and while it had its moments I cannot recommend this game.  My main two issues were the mouse/keyboard controls and the repetitive nature of the second half of the game.Controls:  Probably the laziest effort put forwards on a console port that I've experienced.  Limited ability to rebind the keys, poor mouse utilization, and terrible camera functionality.  I did eventually get used to them, but there could have been so much improvement in the interface displays when using a mouse.  Essentially the mouse is turned into two buttons and there's no cursor.Repetition:  A personal issue but I don't want to have to grind in a single player RPG.  All of the enemies are simply reskins of the same few dozen models.  I ended up limping my way through the end of the game with 5 minute after 5 minute fights since I didn't feel like going out of my way to fight fodder enemies for fractional amounts of EXP.  Boss fights are obnoxiously long and several will take longer than 10 minutes of hitting a button twice every ~5 seconds.  Enemy levels/difficulty are a mystery leading to one shot deaths.  It took me around 35 hours to finish the game.  After the first 15 hours or so I just wanted it to be over.  The last few chapters are quite long.  If you're a fan of excruciating repetition, there are plenty of 'achievements' and completionist objectives.  But I'm glad that it's over and I can free up the 51gb for a new game.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												7/10, would maybe play again.The story is great while the writing can be poor at times, they removed a lot of what made Final Fantasy games special but also added a lot that can be considered innovative and valuable. The battle system was new, interesting, and kept me involved for some time. I was still learning new strategies at the very end of the game. The graphics, of course, are flawless, and since the update for PC they're even better. I never experienced any problems in terms of functionality. I didn't 100% the game because the incentives to complete the side missions were relatively nonexistent and traveling back and forth to complete them became tedious.Overall, I would recommend that someone play through this game at least once. The story really is thought-provoking, and the character design is great; I grew attached to most of the characters and I really cared about the outcome of the game. It has its flaws, but if you know what they are going into the game and can appreciate it for what it has instead of what it doesn't, then you'll have a good experience.

number of helpful: 31 of 64 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I will start off by saying that I used to be a big fan of the FF series and Square's JRPGS of the 90's in general. After Squares PS1 era, I never had the chance or interest in playing any of the later installments in the FF series, mainly because I was exclusively a PC gamer. Then one day I notice to my surprise that they've released this on Steam, so I figured I'd go ahead and try the latest game in the series that I used to be such a big fan of in the past. At first I have to comment on filesize of the game. When installed, the game takes 58 gb's of HDD which is insane!The filesize is that big because the game includes both Japanese and English audio in the game and in the cutscene videos. It really would of been a nice if the original Japanese audio/video was an optional download. That way you would save up about 20gb worth of download time.Now for the actual game:Gameplay:I found the gameplay incredibly boring and repetive. It doesn't have the ATB turn based combat of the previous installments, which I was aware of before I bought this game. Instead it has sort of real-time battle system where you only control one character. You can perform 3 moves in 1 turn and sort of chain different abilities and spells together. Or alternatively, you can just hit the auto-battle and it will automatically choose the best chains for you.Seriously, every battle is the same: Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Heal -> Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Auto battle -> You can unlock new abilities and attributes for your characters with the Paradigms. Basically, your characters have these roles you can choose for them which include offensive, defensive and healing roles. Each of these roles have their own "skill tree" which you can climb to unlock more abilities. The skill tree is as linear as it can get, so theres no actual options to choose from at all. You will simply unlock everything in one order over time. You can also change these roles in combat at anytime when you need to go from doing damage to healing. Its also good to point out that you can't change roles for individual characters in battle.The game doesn't really have any actual RPG depth to it at all. Theres only 2 different stats (Strength and Magic) and only 2 different types of items that you can equip (Weapon and accessory). Can't get much more simplified than that.As for the difficulty of the game. Theres two settings, easy and normal. I played the game on normal and thought it was incredibly easy. None of the boss battles gave me any challenge whatsoever (but then again, how could it with such a simplified gameplay mechanics). The game also recharges your health back to full everytime you win a abttle.Graphics:The graphics are quite alright. The game is about 4-5 years old with initial release on 360 and PS3, so you can't realistically expect anything spectacular. Now that SquareEnix actually managed to get the game to run at 1080p, it looks even better. The game also runs at 60fps, but it has difficulties in maintaining it, so fps drops to 30 are pretty common. My GPU had max GPU usage of 10% when I played the game, so its simply bad optimisation.The art design is where the game actually shines a bit. The characters are all well designed and look good. Most of the areas, landscapes, machines, bosses etc look great.Controls:With the game being a console port, you can expect some not-so-great controls on the keyboard. My biggest gripe was that Esc actually EXITED you out of the game without saving the game (Its now fixed and it asks you if you want to exit instead). I'm pretty sure that any PC gamer will automatically assume that Esc is the menu, not the god damn exit button.Just goes to show that the people at Square Enix who were reponsible for this port, had no idea how a game plays on a PC.Music:The music in this game sounds quite dull in general. Almost like elevator music, with the exception of few tracks in certain parts. They really need to hire Nobuo Uematsu again.Also, theres no final fantasy fanfare. Thats equivalent of not having the blue policebox in doctor who!Story:I'm not gonna go into much detail about the story, but on a personal level, I found it to be quite uninteresting. For the first few hours of the game, I had no idea what the hell was going on at all. It starts you right in the middle of the action and doesn't explain much till later on. I can't comment on the entire story as I have yet to finish the game, but I'm about 12 hours in and it has pretty much failed to spark my interest yet.Characters:I don't really know what to say about the characters in this game. Lightning was ok, though she sort of represented your very standard JRPG pragmatic soldier archetype. Sazh was a funny sidekick with his very handsome afro.Vanille and Snow on the other hand made me want to hit the Esc button more than a few times.Conclusion:The game is INCREDIBLY simplified to the point where it felt like I was watching a mediocre visual novel, rather than playing a game. The game is very easy and offers little challenge. While the game has some redeeming qualities in certain areas, like in the visual design and certain aspects of the story, its not enough to make this game worthwhile at all when the only actual gameplay taking place in the game is you continuously pressing AUTO BATTLE and sometimes switching to heal mode when taking damage.

number of helpful: 24 of 50 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												(This review will mainly be based on the technical side of the game and is made by a normal mortal with common understanding of computers and graphics; AKA the average buyer)This is a long review. Summary at the bottom.--------------- | Graphics: | Score: 9.5/10---------------Okay, first of all, you all need to understand something. I know very well that some reviewers say how the graphics only are at 720p, but it's not that bad at all. After reading several reviews on here waiting for the install to finish, I was scared that it would look messy and laggy on my laptop (read: laptop!), but it far from did. I might not understand much about computers, especially when it comes to graphics, but I do know this: I was breathtaken. Square Enix has done a great job yet again. There's being constructive, and then there's being whiny (Though I suppose that some people only play a game for the graphics, so if you're that person, this game might upset you, apparently). No one ever promised you anything over 720p. You havent been conned, your money hasn't been stolen. It's the same great story, the same great graphics. If it can run this beautifully on my Asus S550C, then I'm sure you'll be just fine - graphics wise, at least.--------------- | Gameplay (Technical): | Score: 7/10---------------If you read the previous section you know that I'm playing this game on an Asus S-series laptop. I suppose this has its challenges prior to a PC (seeing as a PC is bigger and therefore more capable of running big games like FFXIII), however, it hasn't crashed on me yet. The only big issue is the fact that my game froze near the 2nd save station in the beginning when I tried saving, and since I haven't tried again just yet, it could be a one-time error only (I played in Windowed Mode, too, if it helps anything). On the other hand, if it is a recurring issue, I could end up losing a lot of play data from being unable to save, but I'm not going to cry wolf just yet. In fact, this game is running smoother than Skyrim is for me, so I'd say they've done a pretty good job. Some lag, yes, but that's on me. With hardly 10GB left on each drive and the game running alongside a good 150 processes, I wouldn't expect otherwise; the fact that the game is even able to run so smoothly is impressive.--------------- | Gameplay (Battle/combat): | Score: 10/10---------------Everybody knows the classical FF combat system. Although this isn't the exact combat system as the one in FFX (as an example), it's still a lot like it. If you're too slow at striking, your enemies will strike you instead - and you can even strike at the same time. No turn-based combat like that, other than an ATB (attack bar) working the same way as stamina would do with a melee-weapon in any other (J)RPG. Generally easy to control with a keyboard (Unless you've got a controller, which is recommended in the system info). Personally I like the combat style they used for the Kingdom Hearts games, but seeing as this is a game of the Final Fantasy series, it would almost be a shame if it didn't have the CS it has. Either way, it's alright for me.--------------- | Overall impression: | ---------------I've always liked the FF-series, and this game is no exception. Even if the PC version disappoints some, my eyes still lit up like a Christmas tree when I heard it was coming to Steam. I still haven't played it alot (i.e: Look at recorded play time - like you should on any other Steam review), but I know I will. This is one of the only games on Steam that I've bothered reviewing properly, only because I think it's a shame how much it's being downvoted due to its graphics. I'm not saying it was wrong of people to do, as some people genuinely play a game mostly for great graphics, but if you're a fan and usually like the story and the classical turn-based combat (which it isn't quite, but it is), then don't hesitate buying this. However, if you're in doubt, I do recommend buying it when it's on sale to at least tell for yourself if you enjoy it or not. If you don't, you haven't spent as much money as you could've, if you do, then it's a win-win situation. But if graphics is the least of your concerns and you know that your computer can handle running it, then what are you waiting for? ;) SUMMARY: Graphics score: 9.5/10 - Not bad at all, runs fine on a laptop, graphics are really beautiful even though some think it's a downside with "only" 720p (Most likely because they know it's that low prior to the fact that it looks just fine).Gameplay (technical): 7/10 - A few general issues here and there, nothing too buggy but still up for fixing.Gameplay (battle): 10/10 - Final Fantasy style as you know it, with a twist of a more "autonomous" enemy attack system.I hope you found this review useful. And remember, try to not judge so hard just because it's a game of the FF-series.- Lucy.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												I understand those who gave a negative review based on the port and resolution. I also understand those who did not like the "change" in this game as compared to the others.Port and resolution isn't a problem for me. Mainly coz Final Fantasy is beautiful as a game, the sweet graphics is just a bonus. I would still play FF3 and FF4(not even the remakes) now despite it looking all box like lol.I won't lie, I do miss the older versions:-The fighting systems that used HP,TP and MP.-The fact that you can actually flee from an enemy during fights(which is shockingly not here).-Controlling all characters in battle(Here you can only control the leader of the party).-You not being able to see the enemy on the map: You could be walking anywhere then...BAM!!!Fight!!-Most of all, the non-linear aspect: In FFXIII there's a map AND a compass that tells you where to go, and the game is too linear. No one can get lost in this game it's impossible. As for the older games.....they may be a map but there's no compass and it's not linear....your only clue at times to your destination is some old woman saying "Head East...."Yes I do miss all these things, but FFXIII is something new. Whats wrong with something new?You want to play another Final Fantasy Title that has the same mechanics over and over again?its part 13 for Christ's sake a change was needed!!The paradigm fighting method is sweet. It makes you more involved in a fight than the other FF. The constant switching of tactics opens you up to more possibilities to protecting your allies and taking down enemies. The storyline is fine as well. Why are people saying it's confusing?EVERY FINAL FANTASY STORY IN THE BEGINNING IS CONFUSING!!!!It only makes sense when your deep in the game and you know what is really going on.As a long-time Final Fantasy fan, I tell you that this game is totally worth it. The 60GB size may be crippling, but $16 for over 80 hours of playing time sounds like a good deal to me.Final Fantasy XIII is a great game, If you give it a chance you won't regret it. Take my word for it, Although remember I'm just one voice.8.0/10FYI.....Lightning is badass!!!!!!

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												  I haven't completely played through this game; merely a sliver of time in it really. The Final Fantasy series of games has had  a celebrated history of amazing stories, rich and fully fleshed out characters, and soundtracks that put most every other game to shame. Unfortunately since Final Fantasy VI The stories have become more and more confusing and with trying to make a more complex story they continue to bog down the player with trying to find a meaning of it all. This would be wonderful if there was actually hidden meanings written into the storylines. It all started in Final Fantasy VII. Although I'm still hard pressed to call it my favorite (Final Fantasy VI being the best in my opinion.) The story of it started alright and then took a huge turn into the "WTF Zone." Trying to figure out who Cloud was, if he was even in SOLDIER, and what relationship Sephiroth had between him and Zack.   Final Fantasy VIII was a cluster ♥♥♥♥ of WTF moments and I still don't think the ending for that was even a proper ending. IX and X had great stories but with X you had to wait until almost the end of the game to understand anything. XII; while I loved the new MMO play style and the story, the ending was so lackluster I felt like I had just watched Neon Genesis Evangelion when I got to the ending. That being said; I can only PRAY that FFXIII redeems itself to me. It's pretty damn confusing so far with the factions(?) having such closely resembling names. *praying*

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Final Hallway XIII - The greatest casual auto-pilot JRPG in the entire Final Fantasy library.Well this game is a million years old now [obvious hyperbole]... let's talk about it.On to the game play:The first 20-25 hours of the game, depending on how much you love upgrading weapons and accessories, is basically a tutorial that eases you in to the battle system and crafting features.... Once you realize how easy it is, you'll wonder why they even bothered pacing you.It's a FF game catering to mainstream JRPG casuals, just like FFX did years before it... flash some graphical T & A and the bro's come a running. Then they claim to think they know stuff about RPG's and believe they're diverse because they're playing a game outside of their realm of EA sports titles... *sigh* whatever... let them have their piece of candy.This game basically combines the story telling and gameplay progression elements of Final Fantasy IV and the graphical boner inducing glory that was FFX, put them both in a blender and yeah, you get this... a great looking FF game with autism.For the first 25 hours or so you are introducted to our motley crew of characters, their backgrounds, obnoxious personalities and how to set the game on auto-battle and leave it there until you gain some kind of control over your party. The game also introduces the crafting system, albiet a bit briefly and never really explains much other than telling you that you can upgrade your gear and dismantle it or sell it for gil... Bringing me to my next gripe, you never earn gil in this game, only components and computer parts that you can sell for gil... kind of ridiculous in a FF title, no? So needless to say this game is artificially extended by the GRIND. Seriously the game is only about 50 hours long but you'll be grinding materials for over 80+ hours if you expect to get everything in the game maxed out... be warned.The game's maps consist of linear hallways for roughly 80% of the game with only a few area's giving you some room to explore. Nothing is really hidden either, there are literally zero secrets in this game, everything is incredibly obvious and in your face. The map never lies to you either, every area is mapped out properly so once you hit the edge of a map, that's it... there are no hidden path ways... It doesn't leave much to the imagination unfortunately but at least you know you're not going to need a guide book to hit 100% completion.FF13 sets out to tell a story, and that's exactly what it does, it's like the Metal Gear Solid 2 of Final Fantasy games... The game consists of very little game play and mostly cutscenes moving along the drama and unfolding the convoluted and confusing plot. At some point you'll just start disregarding everything everyone is saying so you can auto battle the next colossal, gorgeously rendered monster.It's a great looking game, I'll give it that, it's just not a great Final Fantasy title... they stopped being great after FF6... it's just a sad fact. They all have way to many flaws in them to be considered great additions to the franchise and this is just another one added in to the mix of mixed bag RPG titles. Although I must admit, after playing FFXIII-2... it makes this game seem incredible in comparison.I recommend this game for someone looking for a story to just disappear in to for a few hours a day but as a gamer who enjoys to actually play their games and delve in to things rather than just run back and forth grinding out materials... I'd have to say meh. Thankfully I've already beaten this game years ago and felt like experiencing it again, so I'm in a good mood... other wise I would of just trashed it but in retrospect the game does look beautiful... and I think that's what SquareEnix's original intensions were... to just show case how powerful the new generation of consoles could be.Either way, "bad ports" aside (what did you expect? I mean really?) It's like a 6.5/10 overall.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												So ff 13 is an upgrade in terms of models and textures but a downgrade in terms of gameplay. Truly one of the worst, if not THE WORST final fantasy game I've ever played.(Note: my cons could contain possible spoiler alert.)Pros:- Graphic details and CGI.- weapon upgrade system.- Perfect character model.Cons:(Boy oh boy get ready for this one.)- No more mana system. Now you get to cast infinite magic with no worries of mana management.- You control only one character in a party. Thats right. JUST ONE. Rest are automatic AI control.- During battle, 90% of the time you don't play the game, the game plays for you again because you control only one character.- Hp, Strength and magic. That's it. That's all the attributes you have in this game. No defense, no magic defense, no agility or luck.- Certain negative status effect are gone like blind, confuse (I can see why since this game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ battle mechanic), silence (still there, just that its name is changed to "fog". Like wow.)- Near impossible Eidolon battle. Had to actually look at walkthrough.- Eidolons could morph into ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mounts. (e.g Odin transforms into a god damn horse instead of him riding a horse. Shiva sisters transform into a bike!?!?!?!? WTF really!? This is ridiculous.)- Shiva sisters. Yes, that's right. Suddenly shiva had a twin sister.- No more limit break system like trance of ff9 or overdrive of ffx.- Super long tutorial + boring area. The graphic detail of the levels are no doubt high quality BUT I actually don't give a♥♥♥♥♥about exploring and just rush on through as the level design is boring AF. This is something I never do in a final fantasy game. I rather farm for dark matter from dark yojimbo in ffx then doing this.- Last but not least, the NUMBER ONE bad thing of ff XIII. HOPE. No I'm not talking bout hoping for a miracle, I'm literally talking about the character Hope. A whinny blame everyone for everything little as.11 cons compare to 3 pros. Take note that I loved to 100% the final fantasy series ff4, ff7-ffx including max everything but for this game I just don't bother. The only thing that keeps me going in playing this game is staring at the chick Vanille.I'm not going to say don't buy this game. I'm just going to say this game is NOT WORTH your time and money.

Story: 7/10 Soundtrack: 10/10 Characters:5/10 Graphics: 10/10 Gameplay:9/10As expected of Final Fantasy game it dominates with addictive gameplay and good soundtrack, when it comes to characters however it gets complicated because some characters are very original and lovable but others are full of cliche and have generally boring personalities.However this port is very high quality (if we ignore the lack of graphics settings) and graphics looks even better than it did on the console.What the game lacks in characters it makes up with addictive gameplay in which you can easily lose hours just killing monsters and barely making progress in the story.Some people reported low performance and FPS but i've had no similar experience since the game ran flawlessly.All in all this game is very well worth the money if you are into JRPGS and RPG's in general.It was also announced that sequels will be coming to PC too so if you plan to play it for story be prepared to get the sequels too, for me this is a must have game.

content:

												Ok, after reading the endless waves of rage on the steam forums I decided to buy it and give FFXIII on PC a whirl. So far, very pleased with the "not so wonderful port", and SquareEnix, you have my money for XIII-2 and Lightning Returns! Beats the hell out of dusting off the old PS3 to play...Now on to the nitty gritty...-Pros-Final Fantasy XIII on PCLooks quite good visually for what it's worth (see cons)Controller support (port duh!)FPS of 55-60 constant JPN VA (Vanille = eargasm)-Cons-Locked at 720p   (honestly fullscreen with nVidia tweaks @ GPU Scaling, 16xAF, and 8xSQ AA isn't that bad)Random frame drop to like 2fps (seems only on zone load)Needs audio options, Voices are muffled out by ambience/music-Not Really a Con-60GB DownloadSo those looking to buy, keep in mind, FFXIII is a pure console to PC port, but by no means the best... or worst for that matter... So if you have ever wanted to play FFXIII and never owned a PS3/360 then this PC version (with issues) is worth the buy.Current Specs (just a tiny bit outdated...)Intel Q6600 @ 3.0GHz4GB RAMnVidia GTX 460 1GBScore CardGame: 8 / 10Port: 5 / 10 (future patches will raise this *fingers crossed*)Overall: 7 / 10

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												FF13 is great RPG put in an amazingly beautiful environment. The graphics are hands down some of the best at the time and the visuals are very nice in a lot of areas. Character models and Voice Acting is probably the best in this game (the english voice is kindda weird but its still okay, kudos to the japanesse version definetly worth the extra 25gb). What's ruined is that most areas are mainly narrow paths which I feel is a step back from FF12. Battle system is unique. Square has been trying to keep Final Fantasy's fresh ever since 1 by adding new elements in every game and the Paradigm battle system is one of the worst idea's I think they've ever come up with. It becomes stressful and confusing mixing , matching and switching these to fight certain enemies, bosses and marks. What was wrong with the whole Attack Magic Item Defend style that they felt they needed to get rid of, although it makes the gameplay more exciting rather than passive turn based system. The story is pretty good and the characther are brilliantly develloped eventhough I had trouble getting into it for the first 15 hours or so which was about half of the game for me. Everytime i play a Final Fantasy games the 1st thing i always look forward to is the music but this time I was highly disappointed, it seemed like they used about 4 tracks in the whole game each had some form of rehash or remix, which I felt got old after a while.I agree that Final Fantasy 13 is not as memorable as the older FF but it is the prettiest and probably one of the best looking games in the jrpg scene.Overall i'd Give it 8/10

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												I was asked to write a honest review of this game. So here I am.Short disclaimer: I haven't played any Final Fantasy games for PSX, PS2, PS3, though I played FFVIII and FFVII. Also be wary that I use this "yes/no" option regarding recommendation as a way to answer the question "are you ok with the purchase?"As usual I will start describing the gameplay/game feel. I was expecting a jrpg similiar to any other FF game I've played. Story, party, exploring the word, kinda linear but open world style of gameplay, turn-based battle system.It's really hard to say if I'm happy with that. A lot of people are mad about the part when you get a really extended introduction part where you can't really adjust your gameplay and that really is annoying I have to admit. Game drags you through a lot of tutorials, some of them are helpful, other are completely redundant. This could've been done in a much simplier way, or via a seperate tutorial system. So be wary, you will not feel "freedom" for a lot of time.Let's talk about the battle system/leveling system. It really is different from what I've seen. You're pretty much controlling the leader and the other guys in your party simply follow the AI schema. I'm not saying it's totally wrong since you can just control them with "Paradigms" (AI schemas?), but sometimes it's more of an annoyance. Normally if you wanted to heal a party member using a Cure spell you would just queue a command, choose a target. Here you kinda have to switch your paradigm so your party member actually behaves like a healer and not a damage dealer. He might also just not heal the party member you'd like to heal, which is kind of a problem. Keep in mind: being inefficient about this (letting one follower be a medic 100% of the time) will result in lower battle rating, which is quite crucial as the higher it is, the more of your Technical Points are regenerated (points used to use some special abilities). This enforces a lot of switching, and strategizing as characters may have different roles. You can also setup your own paradigms so that eg. 2 of your fighters will deal damage and 1 will heal, etc.There's a minor issue with leveling I guess. The good ol' "you leveled up!" system was removed. Instead you get Crystarium Points (correct me if I'm wrong), which allow you to get more stats or new abilities. The character development is not linear so you don't get a warning "hey, you can unlock this!", and sometimes checking your Crystarium page so often might be a good (and annoying) idea.The story is a story, it's quite hard to follow, but unveils after a while and you really get the feeling of immersion, which is... good? I mean, usually at the beginning of Final Fantasy games you don't really know what's going on, and then you find out. I think the game is ok in that departament. Some moments and dialogues are pretty cheesy, but well whatever, it's a Final Fantasy game. If you're an anime fan you will be wondering "what the ♥♥♥♥ is he talking about, it's perfectly ok", provided that you play through the game of course.Time to talk about the audio/visual stuff. I will also talk about the PC port here. Music and voice acting are good. Audio fits the atmosphere/area, it's dynamic or slow and calm when it needs to (dialogues/drama/battle). Nothing to worry about here. As mentioned before some of the voice lines are cheesy but it's not like it ruins the game for you.As for the visuals I'll be honest with you: it doesn't really seem that bad to me, though I understand people's concerns about game being run in 720p out of the box (there are some fixes I believe). The areas are very detailed, there's a lot of variety regarding enemies/allies. It's all beautiful. I'm running the game on my laptop and all I was worried about is the performance. I was shocked when I found out THERE ARE NO VIDEO PREFERENCES.Quick rant about the port here: Well I've played older FF games, DMC3, and many other games just butchered by Japanese devs (talking about ports here). This is no different, I could be mad, but I'm not anymore after these years. Game will close if you press ESC (as in quit do desktop without asking). There are no video settings as mentioned before. There's a lot of checkpoints/savepoints in game though so at least you won't be losing much of progress if you accidently quit the game. Also you pause the game with 0 key. Yea, to skip the cutscene you've already seen you need to press 0 on your keyboard, then 1 on your keyboard. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ were they high?After all playing the game feels good. It's certainly no GOTY. It's just... good. I would rate it at 7.5/10, maybe even higher. It's not exactly addictive but you don't quit the game raging after a while, it's totally playable and considering the low price I'd recommend it even more, if you just love the FF beautiful stories, turn-based system games. Well actually, if you don't have a console this is most probably your best bet when it comes to jrpgs (or other FF games released for PC). It's so much better than Last Remnant, that's for sure.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												I'm trying to write down my first impressions here. Tested the game an hour ago.Yesterday I went to work at the time the game content has been unlocked, so I wasn't able to test it immediately. In work, I started to read the reviews and the forums. I've never experinced such hate around a game, ever. We all know the common technical problems, so I won't state them. What's important: I won't defend the flaws, which are definitely there, but I won't take a part in this riot as well. So let's go. First, the positives.I gotta say, the in 720p is not THAT bad. I have a high-end PC, and a monitor with a 1920x1080 pixels resolution. Some have problems with the cutscenes - they're beautiful for me. In the gameplay, it's clear to see that this can be better, but it's not as disturbing as everybody states it.About the FPS: with a GTX 780 videocard, and an i7-4770k CPU, with Win 7 x64, and I have 60 fps every time. When there's a change from cutscene to gameplay the FPS drops down to 40 - for less than a second. Cannot even notice.The Nvidia control panel has great advantages about this one. I feel sorry about AMD users - they NEED a fix. Period.So it is playable, it looks good for me. The major problems I had has all been fixed. There were two.-Immediate crash at the first startup. I had to disable DEP, reset the machine, It works since then.-There was a non-disturbing, but noticeable lag in the game, always. The solution is weird, but this is the only one - you need a controller. The game desperately tries to find a controller in every second, which causes the lag. I have a Dualshock 3 connected, and calibrated as an XBOX360 controller (XInput). It works with the game, and there is no lag anymore.Still, the game needs ingame graphics options, and to support at least 1080p resolution, to meet the VERY minimum of todays PC gaming requirements.I don't think S.E. will do anything about this. The only hope can be Durante, and his awesome work. I tried his early pre-alpha GeDoSaTo fix, it is great already, and it will be more awesome later.Last words: try to think about this another way. This game wasn't meant for PC, unfortunately.If you ever tried to emulate PS2, you know that it is really hard to make everything work, even on a high-end PC.I'm looking at this game as a PS3 emulation, and as we all know: we are ages away from proper PlayStation 3 emulation, and for this price, it is worth for those who wanted to try it, have a powerful PC, but never had a console.A tip: I'm not being the big guy here, I know where I'm came from, I only have built my high-end configuration around three months ago, so my advice is honest and sympathetic here: if you have a low-pc, don't buy it. If you have a mid-pc, you should wait for fixes.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												I don't know why people seem to hate this game so much. I agree the game is very linear in the beginning but what I find fun in this game is the strategy in the combat. Paradigms are what make this game fun, paradigms control what role/skills your characters use when you select that paradigm. Creating/changing your set of paradigms to take down unique bosses and then successfully executing your plan feels awesome. In the beginning of the game it sets what characters you use but once you get through the main story your options really expand. You can select your team members and take on different challenges as their roles are unlocked. You can create new paradigms and gain bonuses from leveling roles. Leveling roles is linear sadly. Not too many options other than what role you want to level even though it may feel like you have options within the roles tree (or should I say vine?). Leveling weapons, I recommend reading and understanding how it works before you "put all of your eggs into one basket". It is very confusing at first but understanding it will help you make the most progress in leveling them.If you give the game some time and pull through the linear-ness and enjoy the story you can have some good fun with it. Especially late in the game.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Super Epic. This is Final Fantasy regardless of whether the haters say so or not. Final Fantasy games always change up, some things you like, some things you might not. The characters are the best since Final Fantsy VI. Just like Resident Evil 6, you have to take the game for what it is, not what you want it to be and you'll enjoy it. It is linear for the first parts of the game, but it opens up on Cocoon and lets you quest and grind. Overall I'm enjoying it. You can see I've played 60 hours so far and I'm not even done with the game.Yeah, it is a straight port. It's not cool that you have to mod it to get higher resolutions, but once you do, it looks much better albeit a bit less stable than I'd like. I save whenever I have the opportunity.Well worth the money, but with all the HD remakes going around, it's a bit disappointing Squeenix didn't make this the definitive version, just by tweaking the code a bit and allowing higher resolutions.Edit: After finishing the game, I still want to go back to Cocoon to finish the C'ieth stone missions. Too bad they didn't let you go back to Cocoon as it changed however. Still, best Final Fantasy yet and I'm aware it could get better AND could have more things like a more open world, etc. Can't wait for FF XV, hope I don't have to wait another 6 years.I also have to add, just like any other PC game, people don't realize resolution goes hand in hand with dpi. I have a 1440p monitor, but it's only slightly higher dpi than my old 1080p 21.5" monitor. If you were to play this on a TV you'd be sitting alot further back and the aliasing would be unnoticalble. Being that this game was mastered for TVs, I find sitting further back from my monitor really makes the details seems alot smoother and more crisp. Either I'll get a lower resolution TV to game on to go easier on my GPU or when GPUs are powerful enough, I'll get a 4K monitor with at least twice the dpi.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												The world of Final Fantasy XIII is stunning. Sadly, we don't get to see enough of it. Calling XIII linear would be an understatement. The game has a deep story with some really interesting characters, watching these characters develop as the story progresses is what Final Fantasy is all about. XIII doesn't fall short in this area.The Visuals and the musical score are beautiful as always, it's a Final Fantasy game after all. For a game released in 2014, the visuals hold up very well against games in 2016.The Crystarium levelling system, while also beautiful to look at, again feels linear. Another sucker punch to the hardcore Final Fantasy fans like myself, is the inability to power level. The Crystarium system locks to each section of the story and puts a halt to over levelling your party. I absolutely recommend FFXIII to hardcore Final Fantasy fans and users that are entirely new to the franchise.A fantastic game yes, but a fantastic Final Fantasy game?

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Before I started to play, I read the dismal reviews and I went ahead and prepared myself for profound disappointment. I don't have a great system; I'm playing on integrated graphics with a processor that barely exceeds the minimum requirements. I've had a few FPS drops, but whatever. I was expecting an ugly mess, and I got a game that looks a little dated, but hey, it's five years old and still really pretty. The controls for keyboard were well mapped (except the notorious ESC key that exits the game immediately), and I didn't have any issues getting my Logitech F310 to work. Technically, I haven't had any major issues with the game.Next comes the reviled linearity. Personally, I adored Final Fantasy X in all its linear glory, and I'm not finding this any more restricting. There's even a later game area (I'm not sure how late; I'm not finished with the game) with vast areas for open exploration and many side quests. Where it's linear, I haven't felt uncomfortable or boxed in. Rather, where it's opened up, I've felt a little agoraphobic even.The story is perfectly sensible. If you pay attention, things will make sense when they're supposed to (and they won't make sense when they aren't, but rest assured that everything so far has been given a perfectly reasonable explanation). You're dropped into the middle of a confusing situation, the narrative is nonlinear, things are explained very slowly and only when it's necessary, and that's all fine and good storytelling. I personally have not felt confused except where I knew I was supposed to be, and anything that felt out of place or like some ridiculous deus ex machina device has been explained in a totally believable way.I expected the characters to be annoying. I heard that Lightning was intolerably selfish, that Snow was basically a cross between Seifer and Zell from FFVIII, that Hope hopelessly whined all the time, and that Vanille was just utterly obnoxious. I haven't gotten that impression yet. I'm spellbound by the characterization because it's all about how the protagonists are processing traumatic events. Every ostensibly annoying thing each character does is a perfectly realistic response to trauma and the narrative does nothing to hide that. In that sense, it's carrying on the tradition of characterization in nearly every Final Fantasy game since IV -- creating strong characters out of their responses to past and present trauma.I know I haven't really covered everything about this game, but I can definitely give it my highest recommendation despite not having played all the way through yet. If you're hesitating because of negative reviews, I say give it a try -- it's very inexpensive compared to the original price on the PS3. If the graphics bother you, there are apparently unofficial fixes, though I haven't even thought to look them up yet. It's a great game with good pacing, compelling characters, and a fast-paced though expansive storyline.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Solely addressing to critics~- Don't like it cause FF changed?That is because video game fandoms are often extremely close minded. FFXIII was not what you would expect from a normal FF game due to it's altered combat system and linear gameplay; True, but many often fail to see it as the game it really is which is a beautiful, in depth and intense story driven one.- Don't like it cause it lacks severe gameplay?Everything has its reasons. The entire battle system is bad just because you CAN auto attack? A little more work needs to be done on that criticism. Are the animations weak? Are the moves choppy? It's no where close. It's there to help those that can't select moves fast enough in the live action and who wants to use it. And to base one's stance on that alone is just a pile of cow manure. There's MOBA and FPS games for that. -Bad graphics and resolution?720p and 30ps is not enough? really? that demanding? Yes the game is locked at 720p but is it really that bad? no. It is not as if you play it on a cinema sized screen anyway. Not to mention this was back in 2009. Does the game have any graphic options? no, not in-game but you can force things like AF and AA through Nvidia control panel if you are that desperate.-Game progressing too slow?It is a ''final fantasy'' afterall, sure you would want that fantasy to last longer. (puns intended) Not to mention, the best way to admire something is to do so slowly. Example: No one rushes and speed glance through artworks in a exhibition gallery or museum.

												The port is not perfect but the game is incredible if you're willing to give it a chance and not listen to the hate brigade. content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Best Final Fantasy hands-down. The visuals are spectacular and the music is in a class of its own. The story-line is amazingly enchanting despite being a little difficult to understand at first. The characters all have unique backstories and personalities, though I do wish they didn't include Sazh as a character since he had no business in being in a Final Fantasy game. I just thought he was unnecessary and took away from the splendor of the game. The battles are amazingly fun and visually pleasing. I LOVE the paradigm system and despite people saying the fact you can only control one character is bad, if you did have control over them, this game would not work, since the battles are way too fast paced for the player to be inputting commands for every character.Pros:- Beautiful visuals. In a league of its own.- Superb soundtrack. Nothing can match. Almost every piece custom orchestrated.- Fun, fast-paced battles.- Thrilling storyline.- Very replayable game.Cons:- Sazh and his son.- Very hard to get gil in this game. And when I say hard, I mean prepare to dedicate a lot of time into farming.- Serah is kind of annoying. Snow too.

It has become abundantly clear that square has given up on the FF  series, especially with the footage from FF15 being released. It's a movie about nothing. It's not a game.I miss what Final Fantasy was. If you're going to hate me for anything I've said, let it be that.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Great music with very soft lyrics that are hard to understand but pleasing to the ear. The characters all look absolutely amazing. There are a lot of cute scenes and personalities. The battle format is relatively simple, to the point of frustrating due to the lack of control you can exert over it.The game itself plays out very similarly to Final Fantasy X on Playstation 2. Some key differences are the lack of swapping during battles, and there is absolutely no backwards exploring possible at any point during the game(unless you count the 'license to hunt marks' quest, which TBH is excessively long, clunky, boring, and thoroughly unrewarding aside from some ocassional monster battles). This in my opinion oversimplifies the game itself and makes it hard to appreciate it through remembering what you've done in the game, since you can't 'physically' take your characters back through the game and revisit various parts of the story. You literally have to either replay the game from start to finish or load up various save points that you made along the way, or else you can't go back to try to jog your memory at all. This is not the same as FFX because at least in that game, with admittedly a great many exceptions, you could backwards explore to jog your memory.The side questing is very limited and totally unrewarding. It also feels forced, as if you have to do the 'side quests' in order to win the game. Well, not all of the quests feel this way. And part of it depends on your attachment to the characters. Still, I felt like most of the fun was in the game's story itself and the side quests just got in the way. It's a far cry from my favorite FF games in that regard. I guess half the problem can be traced back to how incredibly restrictive the game was and how time-consuming it is as a result to actually complete the quests. You literally have to spend like 20 minutes going across terrain just to get started on a quest if you making good time, another 20 minutes embarking on the quest, another 20 minutes completing the quest, and another 20 just getting back to where you started in some cases. That's easily over an hour if you hurry and don't mess up just to do one tiny part of the mark hunting quest.By the time you're able to win the game, you probably powered up your characters just about as much as possible. And then you get to make them even stronger. For what? For more incredibly mind-numbing side-quests? No thanks.One pretty neat thing that could be easily overlooked is the attention to detail with the weapons. You could appear to be holding a completely different weapon depending on what sort of elemental buff your weapon might be enchanted with, if it was indeed affected by a Synergist's spell. And the summons are somewhat entertaining, although you can only have the character you control do the summoning and only for whatever power they have access to. Also, the summons are basically your limit break. You can also use your limit break bar(it's called  Technical Points for whatever reason) for other stuff, but anyway you really have to use it wisely because it's not easy to regenerate at all once you start using it.The game might be worth it for the story and the beautiful music as well as amazing graphics but when it comes to battles and quests it just doesn't deliver fun. Furthermore, if you play the game on your computer, you may experience extremely annoying glitches. One in particular that has plagued me from start to finish is this one where I can't exit the game when I wish to. There is a massive delay most of the time for that. Another one that is probably related is the trouble with alternating between programs while it is running. This can even mean that I have to hit the Start menu button before pressing the function key on my keyboard to either mute or lower/raise the volume. Coupled with the extremely time-consuming side quests, the glitches make this game suck up way too much time.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												With the December update, XIII looks better than ever. Just like in The Last Remnant, the attention to detail in every wall and floor and lush plant is amazing. They have an extremely talented group of artists that make every battle a delight to witness, and every step you take filled with intricate little details that are easy to overlook, but amazing to study once noticed. You don't control every move for each member in your group, you assign them class roles and let them do thier thing. Usually it's helpful, sometimes they do things that make no sense in the moment, like casting a lightning protection spell on each member becuase the single creature you are fighting uses lighthing, even though just adding water to everyones attack would take it out within half a minute. I'm playing on easy so I can get through the story line and start on XIII-2, so every battle is fun and slightly challenging, but not frustrating or needing super studying and planning and perfecting your loadout. I prefer it that way. The last detail I made sure of was to use Japanese voices with subtitles. Just like in my anime, I find the Japanese voice actors to be leagues ahead of the English speaking talent. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to any RPG enthusiast, especially anyone that loves Final Fantasy and Square Enix.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I was going to wait until I completed the game to review it but I decided over 30 hours in is enough time to give it a fair assessment. So how is the port, and more importantly how is the actual game? I'll start with the port itself.A lot of noise has been made about this port if you haven't done any searching around the steam community page or checked the user reviews much. Raging nonsensical rants asside a lot of what is said is true. The lack of resolution settings, graphical settings and sound settings are not available at this point in time. This does bother me and I don't want to say I am thrilled with them being ommitted from the game. All I can really say about it is for the future FFXIII titles they bring to Steam I will hope and expect them to add these options and perhaps maybe even patching this game to add them. On my end though I have had zero crashes, bugs and only on one occurance have I had major frame drops (a quick restart of the game and all was fixed).As far as the game itself goes, I really don't have anything but positives to say about it. First of all, the music is fantastic. I am a fairly novice FF gamer (I've played 10 fully, 11, 14 and parts of 9 and Tactics) and the music is usually one of the best parts of the game. This one does not dissappoint and might even be my favorite of the games I've played. Next I would like to talk about how beautiful some of the zones and scenery are in this game. There have been numerous times throughout the game where I stop just to look around and soak in the environment. For a game that came out in 2009 the graphics still hold up very well and have really impressed me. A few standouts to me were Lake Bresha, Nautilus, Sunleth Waterscape, Gapra Whitewood and Sulyya Springs. There is still more game for me to play so I wouldn't be surprised to see more beautiful areas.The characters are also a positive for me in this game. It seems to be a polarizing topic but to me all of the characters show great development and it is very interesting to find out about how the characters are connected to each other (trying to avoid spoilers here, of course). Lightning is probably my favorite of the chracters to progress. She starts out very closed-minded and standoffish but opens up into a great character.The story is also another positive for me. There have been a few twists and outside of the first 30 minutes or so I've never felt lost. I would definitely recommend reading the data log to fill in any holes the cut-scenes may leave out or just to reassure what you just saw or heard from the characters.A part of the game that you will either hate, like or feel indifferent to (it's impossible not to have an opinion on it) is the linearity. It is definitely a restricted game (for the most part) as to where you can go and how you get there. If you are just interested in a heavily story focused game that doesn't involve tons of exploring you will likely enjoy the game. Personally, I don't mind the linearity of it at all because I am playing for the story and have never been a fan of grinding or getting lost in huge zones with random fights popping up every few steps.When I originally looked into the game for the console I thought the lack of control of all the characters in the combat system would be a turn-off for me. How wrong I was. The combat in this game starts off slow but really picks up the further into the game you get and is an absolute blast. Boss fights always leave me thinking how much fun it was and the need to constantly switch paradigms quickly is chaotic at times. The dificulty level heavily picks up when you get to a completely new location (again, avoiding spoilers) and has challenged me a lot. I wouldn't say the game is overly difficult to the point where you want to throw your controller at the screen but it is far from an easy game. It has a nice balance of very tough and easy fights in-between.Anyways, sorry for the ramble but I just LOVE this game and would definitely recommend it for the price of $15.99 or more power to you if you can get it cheaper. This seems to be a polarizing game but from my end I couldn't be happier with my purchase and hope you will be happy as well if you end up purchasing this title. Can't wait for to finish the game and the series.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Solid but unspectaculary. An attractive and slow moving game that really really eases you into it's moderately shallow world. Long areas that overstay their welcome in some cases. Long expository conversations that overstay almost always. A very poor script undercuts characters that could have made for interesting dramatic moments, even if there are one or two very well made moments in there.Having said all that, the game is relaxing to play for the most part. The battle system really gets going late on, and if you're a completionist then I think there is a lot to sink your teeth into. I personally loved the latter third of the game and taking on the optional bosses. The battle system being relaxing as I said previously helps the grind that the bigger challenges require prior to taking them on.There's about 10-12 hours of decent game in here. Which is worth the €10-12 investment. It may be among the worst of the Final Fantasies, but it is by no means a bad game. It is merely a slightly above average game.All in all, it's the 'Michael Bay - Transformers' version of a Final Fantasy game. It's got pretty explosions, it runs a bit too long, and it has tainted a brand.But that battle music is worth the money alone!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												So, I am a big fan of Final Fantasy. I have played every single version from the original released way back in the nintendo generation before sega. First off, I do have mixed feelings. I loved this game when it first came out. And I still somewhat love it.Pros: Really great graphics, low load for graphics pull on GPU, and of course the in-depth material that allows you to spend day on end completing C'ieth quests and/or missions.Cons: Really obvious emotional extremes, such that characterisation is both typical and stereotypical, the lack of in-depth characterisation makes one feel like they are in a soap opera, the story line is linear but instead of that compelling urge to complete the next step you feel as if you want to drag your feet, Insane storage requirements (50+ GB), and horrible porting system that does not allow you to change brightness, sound, and or framerate. Other issues: the overall scalability between the heroes and the enemies is vast, even maxed you feel desparate. Also, I normally beat all of my RPG's that I own save for a few, where I really don't wish to know the ending. For X-2 I used a gameshark or codebreaker to see the ending back in the day. For this one I watched youtube and/or waited a year to actually beat the game after putting it off on the side because I had found something better. Overall: A graphic designer's dream come true with sappy characterisation that hurts the audiences and/or player's disinterested goodwill, unless the player is imature and/or unable to process emotional understanding.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												First and foremost, it's an extremely bare-bones port. No graphical options, no resolution changes, no nothing. You're getting a direct copy of the PS3 version that just happens to run on your PC, although it does come with the Japanese voice acting, the difficulty setting option from the JP re-release, and it runs at 60 FPS instead of 30 like the console versions. Also, the required specs (and the recommended ones, for that matter) are really low and you'd need a pretty terrible machine to not be able to run it.Aside from that, it's FF13 and you probably already know whether or not you're going to like it. On one hand, it still looks gorgeous even for being 5 years old, the music is pretty good, and the combat's fun. On the other, the story is awful, the pacing is terrible, and it's excessively linear, so if that matters to you stay far away. I like it, and for $16 you could do a hell of a lot worse. To be fair, you could do a hell of a lot better too, but I think it's at least worth giving it a shot.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Love this game.Just to throw it out there, yes, this is a linear Final Fantasy but the story & characters are beautiful, well, most of the characters. The story can throw you off at times (a little bit confusing) but overall it really does consume you.Battles are fun & fast paced but are heavily automated. You only control 1 of your 3 party members in battle, and even then you're mostly just going to be spamming A (auto attack). Strategy is added to the game however with the introduction of the paradigm system, at least for boss battles anyway, you're gonna need a plan.Don't play easy mode, normal mode isn't rediculously difficult, plus your drop rates are downgraded on easy mode & you can always switch between difficulty if you do get stuck.The resolution & shadow/AA additions are also a sweet new addition to the PC edition, making the version look noticeably better than just a console port. Frame rates aren't the best, even on a high-end PC like mine, but it should never drop below 30hz (which is faster than what you could achieve on the consoles!).Great soundtrack, but do I really need to remind you that it's a Final Fantasy?Buy this before 13-2... or any other game for that matter!

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I know that most of you aren't a fan of the linear system in this game.  I give you warning that this game is heavily story based rather than game feature.  If you want to be indulge in a Final Fantasy story and you don't mind the game's linear system.  I would recommend this game.  It sounds a little bias since I myself am a Final Fantasy fan.  I don't like to look at the bad things about Final Fantasy.  Just appreciate the game for what it is.  But if you think you're 60+ hours is worth more for doing other things, I won't stop you.  If you want good gameplay, I recommend you play the Final Fantasy XIII: Lightning Returns (Third installation to the FFXIII franchise).

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I dont understand the negative reviews on the game altogether and now that I am almost 20 hours invested into the game, here is what I would like to share. I have never owned a console after PS1 so my last Final Fantasy game was FFIX and the open world concept was what I have been very used to. Even though there isn't an open world concept, I feel fully immersed in the battle system and the storyline with awesome cutscenes.Perhaps it is due to my lack of history with the original version on the PS3, many people complained about the cutscenes and/or audio which I dont see a problem.The only 2 issue are with the Esc button which I dont face personally as I play it on a controller and the lack of graphical options by forcing the awesome game on a 720p resolution. But if you check online, you will find a way pass the 720p issue and I have been playing it on 1080p from day 1.I look forward to the other ports from Square Enix and hope they do port over the FFIX and other FFs like FFX which I have read that also do not offer the open world concept.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I don't really care if they say this is a bad port from ps3 or xbox360 because it doesn't have Graphic option which is common to all PC game and we can only enjoy it in 720p (there's a mod to make it up to 4K), at least it runs in 60fpsIf there is anything i hate in this game, it is battle system.I spent over 80 hours to play this game, all i did was building characters and paradigm (roles in battle). In battle, i just kept hitting Auto-battle, an option to automatically choose abilities to fight against your enemies base on what you had learnt about them (their weakness, immunity, resistance,...). If their info remains unknown to you, choosing Auto-battle will randomly choose abilities which allow you to learn more about them and sometimes give you disadvantage (there's also a technique called Libra and an item called Librascope, by using them you can learn everything about your enemies immediately), there's also Abilities option which allows you to choose abilities manually if you know what to do, when you face enemies who you learnt everything about them, Auto-battle might be the best option to beat them faster, but it just make the game easier and more boring, it feels like you're not actually the one who play the game but the system itself.Despite of battle system, i still many things in this game like story, soundtrack, cinematics,... Some people say the story is confusing but i don't think it is, cause i don't want any spoiler here. If you want to know more and even enjoy the game, buy then play it.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												People complain about the linearity of this game, but is it really different than any other Final Fantasy? An open world gives the illusion of choice, but the plot of every Final Fantasy game is linear. Rather than letting us "decide" whether to get lost on the world map or not, Final Fantasy XIII gives us interesting tactical choices. Every weapon you find can become an ultimate weapon. Every character is different and useful. The great feeling of trying out parties made up of different roles has been boiled down the core mechanic and we can make this decision many times per battle. I don't think the linearity hurts FFXIII in any way. Rather, I think the useless decisions have been removed and we're left with just the interesting ones.
